feat.name: Dwarven Doughtiness
entries: You are naturally calm and collected in the face of imminent danger. At the end of your turn, reduce your {@condition frightened|PC1} condition by 2 instead of 1.

feat.name: Dwarven Lore
entries: You eagerly absorbed the old stories and traditions of your ancestors, your gods, and your people, studying subjects and techniques passed down for generation upon generation. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Crafting|PC1} and {@skill Religion|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Dwarf Lore}.

feat.name: Dwarven Weapon Familiarity
entries: Your kin have instilled in you an affinity for hard-hitting weapons, and you prefer these to more elegant arms. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=dwarf} with the {@trait dwarf} trait. You have familiarity with weapons with the {@trait dwarf} trait plus the {@item battle axe|PC1}, {@item pick|PC1}, and {@item warhammer|PC1}—for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Mountain Strategy
entries: Dwarves have a long history fighting common foes, and you've mastered the ancient tactics to better face these enemies. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to damage with weapons and unarmed attacks against creatures with the giant, goblin, hryngar, or {@trait orc} trait. If your attack would deal more than one weapon die of damage (as is common at higher levels than 1st), the bonus is equal to the number of weapon dice or unarmed attack dice.

In addition, if any creature critically succeeds at an attack against you and deals damage to you, you gain your bonus to damage against that creature for 1 minute regardless of whether it has the chosen trait.
special: Your GM can add appropriate creature traits to the ancestral foes list if your character is from a community that commonly fights other types of enemies.

feat.name: Rock Runner
entries: Your innate connection to stone makes you adept at moving across uneven surfaces. You can ignore difficult terrain caused by stone (such as rubble or gravel) and uneven ground made of stone and earth. In addition, when you use the {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} skill to {@action Balance|PC1} on narrow surfaces or uneven ground made of stone or earth, you aren't {@condition off-guard|PC1}, and when you roll a success at one of these {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} checks, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Stonemason's Eye
entries: You understand the intricacies of stonework. You become trained in {@skill Crafting|PC1}. If you're already trained in {@skill Crafting|PC1}, you instead gain the {@feat Specialty Crafting|PC1} skill feat for stonemasonry.

You also gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to notice unusual stonework. This bonus applies to checks to discover mechanical traps made of stone or {@condition hidden|PC1} within stone.

If you aren't using the {@action Seek|PC1} action or searching, the GM automatically rolls a secret check for you to notice unusual stonework anyway. This check doesn't gain your normal circumstance bonus.

feat.name: Unburdened Iron
entries: You've learned techniques first devised by your ancestors during their ancient wars, allowing you to comfortably wear massive suits of armor. Ignore the reduction to your Speed from any armor you wear.

In addition, any time you're taking a penalty to your Speed for some other reason (such as from the {@condition encumbered|PC1} condition or from a spell), deduct 5 feet from the penalty. For example, the {@condition encumbered|PC1} condition normally gives a –10-foot penalty to Speed, but this feat would reduce it to a –5-foot penalty. If your Speed is taking multiple penalties, pick only one penalty to reduce.

feat.name: Boulder Roll
entries: Your dwarven build allows you to push foes around, just like a mighty boulder tumbles through a subterranean cavern. Take a {@action Step|PC1} into the square of a foe that is your size or smaller, and the foe must move into the empty space directly behind it. The foe must move even if doing so places it in harm's way. The foe can attempt a Fortitude saving throw against your {@skill Athletics|PC1} DC to block your {@action Step|PC1}. If the foe attempts this saving throw, it takes bludgeoning damage equal to your level plus your Strength modifier unless it critically succeeds.
If the foe can't move into an empty space (if it is surrounded by solid objects or other creatures, for example), your Boulder Roll has no effect.

feat.name: Defy the Darkness
entries: Using ancient dwarven methods developed to fight enemies wielding magical darkness, you've honed your darkvision and sworn not to use such magic yourself. You gain greater darkvision, enabling you to see through magical darkness even if it normally hampers darkvision (such as the darkness created by a 4th-rank {@spell darkness|PC1} spell). You can't cast spells with the {@trait darkness} trait, use item activations with the {@trait darkness} trait, or use any other ability with the {@trait darkness} trait.

feat.name: Dwarven Reinforcement
entries: You can use your knowledge of engineering and metalwork to temporarily strengthen thick objects and structures. By spending 1 hour working on an item, you can give it a +1 circumstance bonus to its Hardness for 24 hours. If you're a master in {@skill Crafting|PC1}, the bonus is +2, and if you're legendary, the bonus is +3. You can reinforce a portion of a structure, though 1 hour usually reinforces only a door, a few windows, or another section that fits within a 10-foot cube.

feat.name: Echoes in Stone
feat.requirements: You are standing on a stone or earthen surface.
entries: You pause a moment to attune your senses to the stone around you. Until the start of your next turn, you gain imprecise tremorsense with a range of 20 feet.

feat.name: Mountain's Stoutness
entries: Your hardiness lets you withstand more punishment than most. Increase your maximum Hit Points by your level. When you have the {@condition dying|PC1} condition, the DC of your recovery checks is equal to 9 + your {@condition dying|PC1} value (instead of 10 + your {@condition dying|PC1} value). If you also have the {@feat Toughness|PC1} feat, the Hit Points gained from it and this feat are cumulative, and the DC of your recovery checks is equal to 6 + your {@condition dying|PC1} value.

feat.name: Stone Bones
feat.trigger: You are struck by a critical hit that deals physical damage.
entries: Your intractable nature can help you shrug off even the most grievous injuries. Attempt a DC {@flatDC 17} flat check. If you are successful, the attack becomes a normal hit.

feat.name: Stonewalker
entries: You have a deep reverence for and connection to stone. You can cast {@spell one with stone|PC1} as a 3rd-rank divine innate spell once per day.

If you have the {@feat Stonemason's Eye|PC1} feat, you can attempt to find unusual stonework and stonework traps that require legendary proficiency in {@skill Perception|PC1}. If you have both Stonemason's Eye and legendary proficiency in {@skill Perception|PC1}, when the GM rolls a secret check for you to notice unusual stonework, you keep your bonus from {@feat Stonemason's Eye|PC1}.

feat.name: March the Mines
entries: You march through the earth and lead an ally along. You gain a burrow Speed of 15 feet when you use this activity (if you don't have a higher one), and then you either {@action Stride|PC1} twice or {@action Burrow|PC1} twice. You can choose one willing ally adjacent to you at the start of your movement to move with you. That ally ends its movement one square behind you.

feat.name: Telluric Power
entries: You channel strength from the earth beneath your feet to pummel your enemies. When making a melee {@action Strike|PC1} against a target who is standing on the same earth or stone surface as you are, you gain a circumstance bonus to the damage roll equal to the number of weapon damage dice.

feat.name: Stonegate
entries: Earthen barriers no longer impede your progress. You gain magic passage as a 7th-rank divine innate spell that you can cast once per day. Unlike the spell, however, this ability can be used only to open passages through barriers of earth or stone.

feat.name: Stonewall
feat.trigger: An enemy or hazard's effect hits you or you fail a
entries: Fortitude save against one.

The strength of stone overcomes you so strongly that it replaces your stout body. You become {@condition petrified|PC1} until the end of the current turn. You don't take any damage from the triggering effect or any other ill effects that couldn't affect stone.

feat.name: Ancestral Longevity
entries: You have accumulated a vast array of lived knowledge over the years. During your daily preparations, you can reflect upon your life experiences to gain the trained proficiency rank in one skill of your choice. This proficiency lasts until you prepare again. Since this proficiency is temporary, you can't use it as a prerequisite for a skill increase or a permanent character option like a feat.

feat.name: Elven Lore
entries: You've studied traditional elven arts, learning about arcane magic and the world around you. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Arcana|PC1} and {@skill Nature|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Elf Lore}.

feat.name: Elven Weapon Familiarity
entries: You favor bows and other elegant weapons. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=elf} with the {@trait elf} trait. You have familiarity with weapons with the {@trait elf} trait plus {@item longbow|PC1|longbows}, {@item composite longbow|PC1|composite longbows}, {@item rapier|PC1|rapiers}, {@item shortbow|PC1|shortbows}, and {@item composite shortbow|PC1|composite shortbows}—for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Forlorn
entries: Watching your friends age and die fills you with moroseness that protects you against harmful emotions. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against {@trait emotion} effects. If you roll a success on a saving throw against an {@trait emotion} effect, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Nimble Elf
entries: Your muscles are tightly honed. Your Speed increases by 5 feet.

feat.name: Otherworldly Magic
entries: Your elven magic manifests as a simple arcane spell, even if you aren't formally trained in magic. Choose one cantrip from the arcane spell list. You can cast this cantrip as an arcane innate spell at will. A cantrip is heightened to a spell rank equal to half your level rounded up.

feat.name: Unwavering Mien
entries: Your mystic control and meditations allow you to resist external influences upon your consciousness. Whenever you are affected by a {@trait mental} effect that lasts at least 2 rounds, you can reduce the duration by 1 round.

You still require natural sleep, but you treat your saving throws against effects that would cause you to fall asleep as one degree of success better. This protects only against {@trait sleep} effects, not against other forms of falling {@condition unconscious|PC1}.

feat.name: Ageless Patience
entries: You work at a pace born from longevity that enhances your thoroughness. You can voluntarily spend twice as much time as normal on a {@skill Perception|PC1} check or skill check. If you do, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to the check and don't automatically reduce your degree of success on a natural 1 (you get a critical failure only if your result is 10 lower than the DC). For example, you could get these benefits if you spent 2 actions to {@action Seek|PC1}, which normally takes 1 action. You can get these benefits during exploration by taking twice as long exploring as normal, or in downtime by spending twice as much downtime.
The GM might determine a situation doesn't grant you a benefit if a delay would be directly counterproductive to your success, such as a tense negotiation with an impatient creature.

feat.name: Ancestral Suspicion
entries: Long-lived elves have seen civilizations rise and fall, often at the hands of outside forces. As a result, they have developed a wariness of others who might seek to influence or control them. You've been trained to resist such manipulation, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to saving throws against effects that would make you {@condition controlled|PC1}, such as dominate, and to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to {@action Sense Motive|PC1} when trying to determine if a creature is under the influence of such an effect. When you roll a success on a saving throw against such an effect, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Martial Experience
entries: You've crossed blades with a wide variety of foes wielding a wide variety of weapons, and you've learned the basics of fighting with nearly any of them. When wielding a weapon you aren't proficient with, treat your level as your proficiency bonus.
At 11th level, you become trained in all weapons.

feat.name: Elf Step
entries: You move in a graceful dance, and even your steps are broad. You {@action Step|PC1} 5 feet twice.

feat.name: Expert Longevity
entries: You've continued to refine the knowledge and skills you've gained through your life. When you choose a skill in which to become trained with Ancestral Longevity, you can also choose a skill in which you are already trained and become an expert in that skill. This lasts until your Ancestral Longevity expires.

When the effects of Ancestral Longevity and Expert Longevity expire, you can retrain one of your skill increases. The skill increase you gain from this retraining must either make you trained in the skill you chose with Ancestral Longevity or make you an expert in the skill you chose with Expert Longevity.

feat.name: Otherworldly Acumen
feat.prerequisites: at least one innate spell gained from an elf ancestry feat
entries: The arcane magic you possess grows in power and complexity. Choose one common 2nd-rank spell from the same tradition as an innate spell you previously gained from another elf ancestry feat (from the arcane list if you have Otherworldly Magic, for example). You can cast that spell as an innate spell once per day, using the same tradition as the list you chose the spell from.
Your magic is adaptable. By spending 1 day of downtime, you can change the spell you chose to a different common 2nd-rank spell from the same tradition.

feat.name: Tree Climber
entries: You've spent much of your life among the treetops and have become an expert at quickly and safely climbing them. You gain a climb Speed of 10 feet.

feat.name: Avenge Ally
feat.requirements: You are within 30 feet of an ally with the {@condition dying|PC1} condition.
entries: Though you know that you will eventually outlive your companions, seeing them at death's door brings clarity to your attacks. Make a {@action Strike|PC1}. Roll twice on the attack roll and use the higher result.

feat.name: Universal Longevity
entries: You've perfected your ability to keep up with all the skills you've learned over your long life, so you're almost never truly untrained at a skill. You reflect on your life experiences, changing the skill you selected with Ancestral Longevity (and the skill you selected with Expert Longevity if you have that feat)

feat.name: Magic Rider
entries: Your people used powerful magic to travel between distant worlds in the distant past, and the remnants of that magic make such transportation easier for you. When you are the target of a teleportation spell that transports more than one person, it can affect an additional person beyond the normal limit, chosen by the caster. Additionally, when you're the target of a {@spell teleport|PC1} spell, you and the other targets arrive no farther than 1 mile off target, regardless of distance traveled.

feat.name: Animal Accomplice
entries: You build a rapport with an animal, which becomes magically bonded to you. You gain a familiar. The type of animal is up to you, but most gnomes choose animals with a burrow Speed.

feat.name: Animal Elocutionist
entries: You hear animal sounds as conversations instead of unintelligent noise, and you can respond in turn. You can ask questions of, receive answers from, and use the {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} skill with animals. In most cases, wild animals will give you time to make your case. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} on animals.

feat.name: Fey Fellowship
entries: Your enhanced fey connection (either through your blood or via prolonged contact with their kind) affords you a warmer reception from creatures of the First World as well as tools to foil their tricks or withstand their magic. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to both {@skill Perception|PC1} checks and saving throws against fey.

In addition, whenever you meet a {@trait fey} creature in a social situation, you can immediately attempt a {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} check to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} on that creature rather than needing to converse for 1 minute. You take a –5 penalty to the check. If you fail, you can engage in 1 minute of conversation and attempt a new check at the end of that time rather than accepting the failure or critical failure result.

feat.name: First World Magic
entries: Your connection to the First World grants you a primal innate spell, much like those of the fey. Choose one cantrip from the primal spell list. You can cast this spell as a primal innate spell at will. A cantrip is heightened to a spell rank equal to half your level rounded up.

feat.name: Gnome Obsession
entries: You might have a flighty nature, but when a topic captures your attention, you dive into it headfirst. You gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} feat and the {@feat Assurance|PC1} feat for the chosen {@skill Lore|PC1}. As gnome obsessions can come and go quickly, you can retrain Gnome Obsession to a different {@skill Lore|PC1} subcategory in 1 day of downtime.

feat.name: Gnome Weapon Familiarity
entries: You favor unusual weapons tied to your people, such as blades with curved and peculiar shapes. You gain access to kukris and all {@filter uncommon weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=gnome} with the {@trait gnome} trait. You have familiarity with weapons with the {@trait gnome} trait plus the {@item glaive} and {@item kukri}—for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Illusion Sense
entries: Your ancestors spent their days cloaked and cradled in illusions, and as a result, sensing illusion magic is second nature to you. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to both {@skill Perception|PC1} checks and Will saves against illusions.

When you come within 10 feet of an illusion that can be disbelieved, the GM rolls a secret check for you to disbelieve it, even if you didn't spend an action to {@action Interact|PC1} with the illusion.

feat.name: Razzle-Dazzle
feat.trigger: You blind or dazzle a creature.
entries: You've spent considerable time practicing the manipulation of light, weaponizing your blade's reflection or bolstering the luminosity of magical displays to unconventional heights.
Extend the duration of the {@condition blinded|PC1} or {@condition dazzled|PC1} condition you give the target by 1 round.

feat.name: Energized Font
feat.prerequisites: focus pool, at least one innate spell from a gnome heritage or ancestry feat that shares a tradition with at least one of your focus spells
entries: You can focus your mind more quickly thanks to the magic that flows within you. You regain 1 Focus Point, up to your usual maximum.

feat.name: Project Persona
entries: Where others etch their armor to serve as a conduit for their imaginations, your vivid mind and bold personality allow you to project a more fitting persona over your lackluster armor. You change the shape and appearance of your armor to appear as ordinary or fine clothes of your imagining. The armor's statistics don't change. This effect lasts as long as you remain conscious and are wearing the armor. A creature can disbelieve the illusion by Seeking or touching your armor. The DC equals your Will DC.

feat.name: Cautious Curiosity
feat.prerequisites: at least one arcane or occult innate spell gained from a gnome heritage or gnome ancestry feat
entries: You've learned a few magical techniques for getting yourself both into and out of trouble {@condition unnoticed|PC1}. You gain {@spell disguise magic|PC1} and {@spell silence|PC1} as 2nd-rank arcane or occult innate spells. The tradition of these spells must match the tradition you use for your gnome ancestry options. You can cast each spell once per day and can target only yourself.

feat.name: First World Adept
feat.prerequisites: at least one primal innate spell
entries: Over time your fey magic has grown stronger. You gain {@spell invisibility|PC1} and {@spell revealing light|PC1} as 2nd-rank primal innate spells. You can cast each of these primal innate spells once per day.

feat.name: Life Leap
feat.requirements: You must be adjacent to a living creature.
entries: You phase through a space that a living creature occupies in a flash, spontaneously appearing on the opposite side of it in a vibrant display of colorful light. You move from your current location to another location that's still adjacent to the same living creature, but on the opposite side or corner of the creature's space. To determine whether a position is valid, use the same rules as for flanking: a line through the center of the two spaces must pass through opposite sides or corners of the creature's space.

You pass through the creature's life force, appearing in the selected location; this doesn't trigger reactions based on movement. You must be able to see your destination, and you can't move farther than your Speed would allow.

feat.name: Vivacious Conduit
entries: Your connection to the First World has grown, and its vital energy flows into you rapidly. If you rest for 10 minutes, you regain Hit Points equal to your Constitution modifier × half your level. This is a healing {@trait vitality} effect and is cumulative with any healing you receive from {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}.

feat.name: Instinctive Obfuscation
feat.prerequisites: at least one arcane or occult innate spell gained from a gnome heritage or gnome ancestry feat
feat.trigger: You are attacked by a foe, but they haven't rolled yet.
entries: The magic within you manifests as a natural reaction to threats. An illusory double of you appears in your space for a brief moment. The triggering attacker must roll a DC {@flatDC 10} flat check; on a success, the attack targets you normally; if they fail, the attack targets the double and destroys it. The tradition of this action matches the tradition of your gnome ancestry options.

feat.name: Homeward Bound
entries: The connection between you and the First World resonates within your body stronger than it does for most gnomes, allowing you to cross the threshold between the Universe and the First World. You gain {@spell interplanar teleport|PC1} as a primal innate spell. You can cast it twice per week. This can be used only to travel back and forth between the First World and the Universe. Due to your body's natural resonance, you can act as a locus for the spell, and you don't require a specially attuned planar key.

feat.name: Burn It!
entries: Fire fascinates you. Your spells and alchemical items that deal fire damage gain a status bonus to damage equal to half the spell's rank or one-quarter the item's level (minimum bonus +1). You also gain a +1 status bonus to any {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent fire damage} you deal.

feat.name: City Scavenger
entries: You know that the greatest treasures often look like refuse. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to checks to {@action Subsist|PC1}, and you can use {@skill Society|PC1} or {@skill Survival|PC1} when you {@action Subsist|PC1} in a settlement.

When you {@action Subsist|PC1} in a city, you also gather valuable junk that silly longshanks threw away. You can {@action Earn Income|PC1} using {@skill Society|PC1} or {@skill Survival|PC1} at the same time while you {@action Subsist|PC1}, without spending any additional days of downtime. You also gain a +1 circumstance bonus to this check.
special: If you have the irongut goblin heritage, increase the bonuses to +2.

feat.name: Goblin Lore
entries: You've picked up skills and tales from your goblin community. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Nature|PC1} and {@skill Stealth|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Goblin Lore}.

feat.name: Goblin Scuttle
feat.trigger: An ally ends a move action adjacent to you.
entries: You take advantage of your ally's movement to adjust your position. You {@action Step|PC1}.

feat.name: Goblin Song
entries: You sing annoying goblin songs, distracting your foes with silly and repetitive lyrics. Attempt a {@skill Performance|PC1} check against the Will DC of a single enemy within 30 feet. This has all the usual traits and restrictions of a {@skill Performance|PC1} check to sing. You can affect up to two targets within range if you have expert proficiency in {@skill Performance|PC1}, four if you have master proficiency, and eight if you have legendary proficiency.

Critical Success: The target takes a –1 status penalty to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks and Will saves for 1 minute.
Success: The target takes a –1 status penalty to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks and Will saves for 1 round.
Critical Failure: The target is temporarily immune to Goblin Song for 1 hour.

feat.name: Goblin Weapon Familiarity
entries: Others might look upon them with disdain, but you know that the weapons of your people are as effective as they are sharp. You gain access to all uncommon weapons with the {@trait goblin} trait. You have familiarity with {@filter weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=goblin} with the {@trait goblin} trait—for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Junk Tinker
entries: You can make useful tools out of even twisted or rusted scraps. When using the {@skill Crafting|PC1} skill to {@action Craft|PC1}, you can make level 0 items, including weapons and armor, out of junk. This reduces the Price to one-quarter the usual amount but always results in a shoddy item. Shoddy items normally give a penalty, but you don't take this penalty when using shoddy items you made (nor does the worse check penalty of shoddy armor you made apply to you).

You can also incorporate junk to save money while you {@action Craft|PC1} any item. This grants you a discount on the item as if you had spent 1 additional day working to reduce the cost, but the item is obviously made of junk. At the GM's discretion, this might affect the item's resale value depending on the buyer's tastes.

feat.name: Rough Rider
entries: You are especially good at riding traditional goblin mounts. You gain the {@feat Ride|PC1} feat, even if you don't meet the prerequisites. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Nature|PC1} checks to use {@action Command an Animal|PC1} on a goblin dog or wolf mount.
If you gain a wolf as an animal companion, it gains the mount special ability (and if you gain an ability that grants you an animal companion with the mount special ability, you can choose a wolf).

feat.name: Very Sneaky
entries: Taller folk rarely pay attention to the shadows at their feet, and you take full advantage of this. You can move 5 feet farther when you take the {@action Sneak|PC1} action, up to your Speed. In addition, as long as you continue to use {@action Sneak|PC1} actions and succeed at your {@skill Stealth|PC1} check, you don't become {@condition observed|PC1} if you don't have cover or greater cover and aren't {@condition concealed|PC1} at the end of the {@action Sneak|PC1} action, as long as you have cover or greater cover or are {@condition concealed|PC1} at the end of your turn.

feat.name: Kneecap
entries: You deliver a punishing blow to an enemy's knee, shin, or other vulnerable anatomy within your reach. Make a melee {@action Strike|PC1} with a melee weapons or melee unarmed attack. This attack doesn't deal damage. On a hit, the target takes a –10-foot status penalty to its Speed (or a –15-foot status penalty on a critical hit). The penalty lasts for 1 round. This penalty applies only if the target has a land Speed and depends on legs or other targetable appendages to use its land Speed. As with all penalties to Speed, this can't reduce a creature's Speed below 5 feet.

feat.name: Loud Singer
entries: Staying on pitch, proper breath control, and remembering the words are all less important than the real measure of a good singer: volume! The range of your Goblin Song is increased to 60 feet, and you can target one additional enemy when you use it.

feat.name: Vandal
entries: You have a knack for breaking and dismantling things. Putting them back together is the boring part, so you largely don't bother with that. You become trained in {@skill Thievery|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in {@skill Thievery|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
In addition, whenever you hit with a {@action Strike|PC1} against a trap or an unattended object, you ignore the first 5 points of the object's Hardness.

feat.name: Cave Climber
entries: After years of clambering through caverns, you can climb easily anywhere you go. You gain a climb Speed of 10 feet.

feat.name: Cling
feat.requirements: Your last action was a successful {@action Strike|PC1} and you have a free hand.
entries: You hang onto a foe to harry them into submission. If your target moves while you're hanging onto it, you can choose to move with the target. The target is released if you choose not to move with it, at the start of your next turn, or if the target Escapes. Attempts to {@action Escape|PC1} from a Cling are made against your {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} DC and follow the rules on page 416, but they end the Cling instead of the conditions normally ended by the {@action Escape|PC1} action.
special: You can use this action without a free hand if your preceding {@action Strike|PC1} was made with your jaws or a similar unarmed attack you could use to hang on. The GM determines which unarmed attacks apply. Hanging on in this way prevents you from using that unarmed attack.

feat.name: Skittering Scuttle
entries: You can scuttle farther and faster when maneuvering alongside allies. When you use Goblin Scuttle, you can {@action Stride|PC1} up to half your Speed instead of Stepping.

feat.name: Very, Very Sneaky
entries: You can move up to your Speed when you use the {@action Sneak|PC1} action, and you no longer need to have cover or greater cover or be {@condition concealed|PC1} to {@action Hide|PC1} or {@action Sneak|PC1}.

feat.name: Reckless Abandon
entries: Despite a lifetime filled with questionable decisions, you've managed to survive, as though you have uncanny luck that lets you avoid the consequences of your own actions. For the remainder of your turn, if you roll a failure or critical failure on a saving throw against a harmful effect, you get a success instead. Further, if you would take damage from an enemy or hazard this turn you take the minimum possible damage.

These benefits apply only to harmful effects incurred entirely during your turn in which you activate Reckless Abandon, such as running through a wall of fire. {@condition persistent damage|PC1} and conditions that were applied prior to your turn proceed normally, and as soon as your turn ends you are subject to the full consequences of any dangers still threatening you.

feat.name: Distracting Shadows
entries: You have learned to remain {@condition hidden|PC1} by using larger folk as a distraction to avoid drawing attention to yourself. You can use creatures that are at least one size larger than you (usually Medium or larger) as cover for the {@action Hide|PC1} and {@action Sneak|PC1} actions, though you still can't use such creatures as cover for other uses, such as the {@action Take Cover|PC1} action.

feat.name: Folksy Patter
entries: You are adept at disguising coded messages as folksy idioms. Using slang, jokes, halfling loanwords, and the like, you convey a simple message consisting of three basic words (such as "Danger assassin flee" or "Meet me moonrise"). Your intended listener can attempt a DC 20 {@skill Perception|PC1} check to discern the message.

This DC is reduced by 5 if the listener is a halfling or has Folksy Patter, or by 10 if both apply. Eavesdroppers can also attempt a {@skill Perception|PC1} check against your {@skill Deception|PC1} DC to discern your meaning. Any bonuses or penalties to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to {@action Sense Motive|PC1} apply to checks to understand Folksy Patter.

feat.name: Halfling Lore
entries: You've dutifully learned how to keep your balance and how to stick to the shadows where it's safe, important skills passed down through generations of halfling tradition. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} and {@skill Stealth|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Halfling Lore}.

feat.name: Halfling Luck
feat.trigger: You fail a skill check or saving throw.
entries: Your happy-go-lucky nature makes it seem like misfortune avoids you, and to an extent, that might even be true. You can reroll the triggering check, but you must use the new result, even if it's worse.

feat.name: Halfling Weapon Familiarity
entries: You favor traditional halfling weapons, so you've learned how to use them more effectively. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=halfling} with the {@trait halfling} trait. You have familiarity with weapons with the {@trait halfling} trait plus the {@item sling} and {@item shortsword}— for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Prairie Rider
entries: You grew up riding your clan's shaggy ponies and riding dogs. You become trained in {@skill Nature|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in {@skill Nature|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also get a +1 circumstance bonus to {@action Command an Animal|PC1} if the target is a traditional halfling mount, such as a pony or riding dog

feat.name: Sure Feet
entries: Whether keeping your balance or climbing, your feet easily find purchase. If you roll a success on an {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} check to {@action Balance|PC1} or an {@skill Athletics|PC1} check to {@action Climb|PC1}, you get a critical success instead.
You're not {@condition off-guard|PC1} when you attempt to {@action Balance|PC1} or {@action Climb|PC1}.

feat.name: Titan Slinger
entries: You have learned how to use your sling to fell enormous creatures.
When you hit on an attack with a weapon of the sling group against a Large or larger creature, increase the size of the weapon damage die by one step.

feat.name: Unfettered Halfling
entries: You were either pressed into indentured servitude or shackled in a prison, but you've since escaped and have trained to ensure you'll never be caught again. Whenever you roll a success on a check to {@action Escape|PC1} or a saving throw against an effect that would impose the {@condition grabbed|PC1}, {@condition immobilized|PC1}, or {@condition restrained|PC1} condition on you, you get a critical success instead. Whenever a creature rolls a failure on a check to {@action Grapple|PC1} you, it gets a critical failure instead.

feat.name: Watchful Halfling
entries: You pay close attention to the people around you, allowing you to more easily notice when they act out of character. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks when using the {@action Sense Motive|PC1} basic action to notice enchanted or possessed characters. If you aren't actively using {@action Sense Motive|PC1} on an enchanted or possessed character, the GM rolls a secret check, without your usual circumstance bonus, for you to potentially notice the enchantment or possession anyway.

In addition to using it for skill checks, you can use the {@action Aid|PC1} basic action to grant a bonus to another creature's saving throw or other check to overcome enchantment or possession. As usual for {@action Aid|PC1}, you need to prepare by using an action on your turn to encourage the creature to fight against the effect

feat.name: Cultural Adaptability
entries: During your adventures, you've honed your ability to adapt to the culture of the predominant ancestry around you. You gain the {@feat Adopted Ancestry|PC1} general feat, and you also gain one 1st-level ancestry feat from the ancestry you chose for the {@feat Adopted Ancestry|PC1} feat.

feat.name: Step Lively
feat.trigger: A Large or larger enemy ends a move action adjacent to you.
entries: You are an expert at avoiding the lumbering footsteps of larger creatures. You {@action Step|PC1} to another space adjacent to the enemy.

feat.name: Dance Underfoot
entries: You dart under the legs of your enemies in combat. You can end a successful {@action Tumble Through|PC1} action in a Large or larger enemy's space. Also, when using the {@feat Step Lively|PC1} feat, you can {@action Step|PC1} into the triggering enemy's space. The enemy must have limbs or otherwise leave you enough room for this maneuver, as determined by the GM. For instance, you could share space with a giant or dragon, but not an ooze.

feat.name: Guiding Luck
entries: Your luck guides you to look the right way and aim your blows unerringly. You can use Halfling Luck twice per day: once in response to its normal trigger, and once when you fail a {@skill Perception|PC1} check or attack roll instead of the normal trigger.

feat.name: Irrepressible
entries: You are easily able to ward off attempts to play on your fears and emotions. When you roll a success on a saving throw against an {@trait emotion} effect, you get a critical success instead.
If your heritage is gutsy halfling, when you roll a critical failure on a saving throw against an {@trait emotion} effect, you get a failure instead.

feat.name: Unhampered Passage
entries: You won't allow others to restrain you. You can cast {@spell unfettered movement|PC1} on yourself as a primal innate spell once per day.

feat.name: Ceaseless Shadows
entries: You excel at going {@condition unnoticed|PC1}, especially among a crowd. You no longer need to have cover or be {@condition concealed|PC1} to {@action Hide|PC1} or {@action Sneak|PC1}. If you would have lesser cover from a creature, you gain standard cover instead and can {@action Take Cover|PC1}; if you would have standard cover from a creature, you gain greater cover instead.

feat.name: Toppling Dance
entries: While sharing a creature's space using Dance Underfoot, your melee weapons and unarmed attacks gain the {@trait trip} trait, but only against the creature whose space you share. You can be in the same space as a Large or larger {@condition prone|PC1} creature, even if it's not your ally.

feat.name: Shadow Self
feat.trigger: You successfully use {@skill Stealth|PC1} to {@action Hide|PC1} and become {@condition hidden|PC1} from all your current foes, or use {@skill Stealth|PC1} to {@action Sneak|PC1} and become {@condition undetected|PC1} to all your current foes.
entries: You slip from your adversaries' notice and appear to be somewhere else. You become {@condition invisible|PC1} for 1 minute or until you take a {@condition hostile|PC1} action, whichever comes first. Choose a location within 10 feet of you. Until your invisibility ends, you appear to be {@condition hidden|PC1} in that location to anyone trying to find you. If the searcher gets clear evidence that you're not there, they no longer think you're {@condition hidden|PC1} there, but they don't discover your actual location.

feat.name: Grasping Reach
entries: You can extend a tangle of vines or tendrils to support your arms and extend your reach. When you wield a melee weapon that requires two hands, doesn't have reach, and deals at least {@dice 1d6} damage, you can change between a typical two-handed grip and an extended two-handed grasp using an {@action Interact|PC1} action. Weapons wielded in your extended grasp gain reach of 10 feet. This grasp is less stable and powerful than a typical grip, reducing the weapon's damage die by 1 step.

feat.name: Harmlessly Cute
entries: Your size and demeanor make it easy for you to convince others that you mean no harm. You gain the {@feat Shameless Request|PC1} skill feat as a bonus feat. Additionally, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to initiative checks when you roll {@skill Deception|PC1} for initiative.

feat.name: Leshy Lore
entries: You deeply understand your people's cultural traditions and innate strengths. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Nature|PC1} and {@skill Stealth|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Leshy Lore}.

feat.name: Leshy Superstition
feat.trigger: You attempt a saving throw against a spell or {@trait magical} effect, but haven't rolled yet.
entries: You notice spirits that inhabit objects, learning which bring good fortune and which are unlucky. You focus on the power of a lucky object, granting you a +1 circumstance bonus to your saving throw against the triggering effect.

feat.name: Seedpod
entries: Your body produces a nearly endless supply of hard seedpods. You gain a seedpod ranged unarmed attack with a range increment of 30 feet that deals {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage. On a critical hit, a seedpod bursts, issuing forth a tangle of vegetation that imposes a –10-foot circumstance penalty on the target's Speed until the start of your next turn. Seedpods do not add critical specialization effects.

feat.name: Shadow of the Wilds
entries: It's difficult to notice your passage through wild areas. As long as you're not in an urban environment, you're always considered to be {@action Cover Tracks||Covering Tracks}, even if you chose a different activity in exploration mode.

feat.name: Undaunted
entries: Your spirit has endured many challenges over its long existence. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saves against {@trait emotion} effects. If you roll a success on a saving throw against an {@trait emotion} effect, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Anchoring Roots
entries: Small roots sprout from your feet, steadying you as you move. You gain the {@feat Steady Balance|PC1} skill feat, even if you aren't trained in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, and you can use the Anchor action.

entries.name: Anchor
entries: You send your roots into or across the ground, making it harder for you to stumble. Until you move, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to your Fortitude or Reflex DC against attempts to {@action Reposition|PC1}, {@action Shove|PC1}, or {@action Trip|PC1} you (or a +4 circumstance bonus if you're a root leshy). This bonus also applies to saving throws against spells or effects that attempt to move you or knock you {@condition prone|PC1}. If an effect forces you to move, you move only half the normal distance, as some of the effort goes to tearing loose the roots.

feat.name: Leshy Glide
feat.prerequisites: leaf leshy heritage or {@feat Cat Fall|PC1} skill feat
entries: Using your own leaves, you can control your descent. You glide slowly toward the ground, 5 feet down and up to 25 feet forward through the air. As long as you spend at least 1 action gliding each round and have not yet reached the ground, you remain in the air at the end of your turn.

feat.name: Ritual Reversion
entries: You can temporarily revert to a less conspicuous form without diminishing your senses. You take the form of an ordinary specimen of the type of plant or fungus that most closely resembles you, reverting to your body's appearance just before your spirit joined with it. This otherwise has the effects of one with plants, except that your size remains Small.

feat.name: Speak with Kindred
entries: You have a connection with creatures that share your physiology. You can ask questions of, receive answers from, and use the {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} skill with plants and fungi. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} checks with plants or fungi of your kind. Generally, fungus leshies get this bonus with mushrooms and fungi; gourd leshies with gourds, melons, and similar fruiting plants; leaf leshies with deciduous trees; and vine leshies with vines and climbing plants.

feat.name: Bark and Tendril
entries: You wield primal magic. You can cast {@spell entangling flora|PC1} and {@spell oaken resilience|PC1} as 2nd-rank primal innate spells once per day each.

feat.name: Lucky Keepsake
entries: You have a keepsake that grants you luck. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saves against spells and {@trait magical} effects at all times, not just when you use {@feat Leshy Superstition|PC1}. If you lose the keepsake, you lose the bonus until you designate a new keepsake, typically over the course of a week.

feat.name: Solar Rejuvenation
entries: If you rest outdoors for 10 minutes during the day, you regain Hit Points equal to your Constitution modifier × half your level.

You gain this benefit in addition to any healing from {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}. Leshies whose plant nourishment does not rely on photosynthesis require a similarly suitable environment. For example, fungus leshies need dark, damp environments and a pile of decaying plant matter.

feat.name: Thorned Seedpod
entries: When your seedpods strike a felling blow, they burst into viciously thorny vines. When you critically succeed at a seedpod {@action Strike|PC1}, vines twist and stab your foe, dealing {@damage 1d4} {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent piercing damage}.

feat.name: Call of the Green Man
entries: You can call forth nearby nature spirits to augment your body. Once per day, you can cast {@spell plant form|PC1} as a 5th-rank primal innate spell.
When you reach 17th level, you can heighten the spell to 6th rank when you cast it.

feat.name: Cloak of Poison
entries: You secrete a cloak of concentrated poison that harms any who dare attack you. For 1 minute, any creature that touches you or damages you with an unarmed attack or melee weapon without the {@trait reach} trait takes {@damage 3d6} poison damage.

feat.name: Flourish and Ruin
entries: You can call upon the vital essence of your spirit to restore life to your allies and call forth vines to ensnare and bludgeon your foes. You can cast {@spell field of life|PC1} and {@spell tangling creepers|PC1} as 6th-rank primal innate spells once per day each.

feat.name: Regrowth
entries: Your command over your vital essence allows you or an ally to recover from grievous wounds. You can cast {@spell regenerate|PC1} as a 7th-rank primal innate spell once per day.

feat.name: Beast Trainer
entries: You have an impressive innate ability to tame and command ferocious beasts. You become trained in the {@skill Nature|PC1} skill and gain your choice of the Pet general feat or the {@feat Train Animal|PC1} skill feat.

feat.name: Iron Fists
entries: Your fists have been forged by battle, your naturally tough skin and dense bone further hardened by conflict. Your fist unarmed attacks no longer have the {@trait nonlethal} trait and gain the {@trait shove} weapon trait

feat.name: Orc Ferocity
feat.trigger: You would be reduced to 0 Hit Points but not immediately killed.
entries: Fierceness in battle runs through your blood, and you refuse to fall from your injuries no matter how terrible they may be. You avoid being knocked out and remain at 1 Hit Point, and your {@condition wounded|PC1} condition increases by 1.

feat.name: Orc Lore
entries: The hold elders taught you your people's histories, told tales of great athletic feats, and shared with you the hardships your ancestors endured so that you can pass this wisdom down to future generations. You become trained in {@skill Athletics|PC1} and {@skill Survival|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Orc Lore}.

feat.name: Orc Superstition
feat.trigger: You attempt a saving throw against a spell or {@trait magical} effect, and have not yet rolled.
entries: You defend yourself against magic by relying on techniques derived from orc cultural superstitions. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your saving throw against the triggering spell or {@trait magical} effect.

feat.name: Hold Mark
entries: You bear scars or tattoos enhanced by the mark of your community's prowess. When you select this feat, choose one of the options from the below table. You are trained in the listed skill and gain a +1 status bonus to saves against spells from the listed tradition. You gain a large brand or tattoo in the shape of the chosen emblem or a similar concept (for example, the Burning Sun could be a torch, sun, volcano, or other fiery symbol, while the Empty Hand could be a fist or claw).

feat.name: Orc Weapon Familiarity
entries: In combat, you favor the brutal weapons that are traditional for your orc ancestors. You gain access to all {@filter uncommon weapons|items||Category=Weapon|rarity=uncommon|ancestry & heritage=orc} with the {@trait orc} trait. You have familiarity with weapons with the {@trait orc} trait plus the {@item falchion|PC1} and {@item greataxe|PC1}—for the purposes of proficiency, you treat any of these that are martial weapons as simple weapons and any that are advanced weapons as martial weapons.
At 5th level, whenever you get a critical hit with one of these weapons, you get its critical specialization effect.

feat.name: Tusks
entries: You have particularly long, jagged tusks perfect for tearing meat from bone. You gain a tusks unarmed attack that deals {@damage 1d6} piercing damage. Your tusks are in the brawling group and have the {@trait finesse} and {@trait unarmed} traits.
special: You can take this feat only at 1st level, and you can't retrain into this feat. You can retrain out of this feat only through drastic measures, such as breaking, filing, or extracting your tusks.

feat.name: Athletic Might
entries: Surviving in {@condition hostile|PC1} terrain has given you a great talent for mobility. Whenever you roll a success on an {@skill Athletics|PC1} check to {@action Climb|PC1} or {@action Swim|PC1}, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Bloody Blows
entries: Your lethal unarmed attacks leave bloody gouges or cause severe internal bleeding. When you critically hit with a {@action Strike|PC1} using an unarmed attack that isn't nonlethal, the target takes {@damage 1d4} {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent bleed damage}. This can be because you're taking the penalty to use a fist for a lethal attack or because you have an unarmed attack without the {@trait nonlethal} trait due to Tusks or a similar ability.

feat.name: Defy Death
entries: You're exceptionally difficult to kill. The DC of your recovery checks is equal to 9 + your {@condition dying|PC1} value, or 8 + your {@condition dying|PC1} value if you have the {@feat Toughness|PC1} general feat. In addition, whenever someone returns you to life using magic that would normally leave you debilitated for a week (such as {@ritual raise dead|PC1} or the {@ritual resurrect|PC1} ritual), you don't suffer that condition.

feat.name: Scar-Thick Skin
entries: Glorious, storied scars cover and protect much of your body, girding you in fleshly armor that resists any wound weaker than those you have already survived. Your DC on flat checks to end {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent bleed damage} is reduced from 15 to 10, or from 10 to 5 after receiving especially appropriate assistance.

feat.name: Pervasive Superstition
entries: You steep yourself in superstition and practice ancient orc mental exercises for shrugging off the effects of magic. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against spells and {@trait magical} effects at all times.

feat.name: Undying Ferocity
entries: You resist death's clutches with supernatural vigor, daring death to claim you while promising that any such attempt will surely fail. When you use {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1}, you gain temporary Hit Points equal to your level.

feat.name: Incredible Ferocity
entries: Given time to collect yourself after a near-death scrape, you can rebuild your ferocity and withstand additional finishing blows. You can use {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1} with a frequency of once per hour, rather than once per day.

feat.name: Ferocious Beasts
feat.prerequisites: animal companion, Pet, or Bonded Animal; {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1}
entries: Since ancient times, the mightiest orc beast tamers would draw out the true fighting spirit of their companion beasts by feeding the creatures a draft incorporating the orc's own blood. All animal companions, pets, familiars, and bonded animals you have gain the {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1} feat, and gain one reaction per round they can use only for {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1}. If you have the {@feat Undying Ferocity|PC1} ancestry feat, all animal companions, pets, familiars, and bonded animals you have also gain the benefits of that feat when using the {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1} reaction.

feat.name: Spell Devourer
entries: You don't just resist magic; you devour it. Whenever you succeed at a saving throw against a spell or {@trait magical} effect, you gain temporary Hit Points equal to double the spell's rank, or equal to the level if the {@trait magical} effect isn't a spell. These temporary Hit Points last until the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Rampaging Ferocity
feat.trigger: You use {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1}.
entries: You lash out viciously even as you fend off death. Make a single melee {@action Strike|PC1}. If this {@action Strike|PC1} brings a foe to 0 Hit Points, this activation of {@feat Orc Ferocity|PC1} doesn't count against its frequency.

feat.name: Brine May
entries: Your mother was a sea hag, granting you one sea-green or blue eye. You find comfort both in the sea and on the shore. Whenever you roll a success on an {@skill Athletics|PC1} check to {@action Swim|PC1}, you get a critical success instead. If you end your turn in water without having succeeded at a {@action Swim|PC1} action that round, you don't sink (but you might still be moved by the current).

feat.name: Callow May
entries: You are among the most common of changelings—those born to sweet hags—and a vibrant green eye signifies that parentage. Your mother's manipulative nature and versatile voice gives you an edge when deceiving others. You gain the {@feat Charming Liar|PC1} skill feat. If you roll {@skill Deception|PC1} for initiative, foes in that combat encounter that haven't acted yet are {@condition off-guard|PC1} against you.

feat.name: Dream May
entries: You are the child of a cuckoo hag, making one of your eyes violet or even black. Your mother's powers over sleep and dreams have given you a degree of resistance to those effects, granting you a +2 circumstance bonus to all saving throws against {@trait sleep} effects and effects that cause or alter dreams.

In addition, sleep is more restorative for you. You regain HP equal to your Constitution modifier × double your level (instead of just × your level), and you reduce any {@condition drained|PC1} and {@condition doomed|PC1} conditions you have by 2 instead of by 1.

feat.name: Slag May
entries: Your mother was an iron hag known for physical prowess, and you have one violet or steel-gray eye. You have thick, sturdy claws made of cold iron that grow naturally from your body.
You gain a claw unarmed attack that deals {@damage 1d6} slashing damage. Your claws are in the brawling group, have the {@trait unarmed} and {@trait grapple} traits, and are cold iron.

feat.name: Changeling Lore
entries: All too aware of your true nature, you've studied hags and their powers. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Deception|PC1} and {@skill Occultism|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for {@skill Lore|PC1|Hag Lore}.

feat.name: Hag Claws
entries: When you came of age, your fingernails grew long and sharp. You gain a claw unarmed attack that deals {@damage 1d4} slashing damage.
Your claws are in the brawling group and have the agile, {@trait finesse}, and {@trait unarmed} traits.
special: Hag claws can develop at any point in a changeling's life. You can select this feat anytime you would gain an ancestry feat, but you can't retrain out of it.

feat.name: Hag's Sight
entries: You've nurtured the supernatural abilities gifted by your hag mother, particularly your sight. You gain darkvision.

feat.name: Called
entries: You've heard the Call, and by resisting it, you've developed a bulwark against effects that target your mind. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to Will saving throws against {@trait mental} effects.
If you roll a success on your saving throw against a {@trait mental} effect that would make you {@condition controlled|PC1}, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Mist Child
entries: You blend in with unnatural subtlety. When you are {@condition concealed|PC1} or {@condition hidden|PC1}, increase the DC of the flat check to target you to 6 if you're {@condition concealed|PC1} or 12 if you're {@condition hidden|PC1}.

feat.name: Accursed Claws
entries: Your claws carry your mother's hag magic. When you critically hit with a claw {@action Strike|PC1}, the target takes an additional {@damage 1d4} {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent mental damage}.

feat.name: Occult Resistance
entries: Your study of occult practices has shown you how to best defend against them. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to all saving throws against {@trait occult} effects.

feat.name: Hag Magic
entries: Through your heritage, you can replicate a hag's magic. Choose one common spell of 4th rank or lower from those available to a coven, including the spells contributed to a coven by a hag of your mother's type. You can cast this spell once per day as a 4th-rank occult innate spell.

Spells available to all covens are {@spell augury|PC1}, {@spell charm|PC1}, {@spell clairaudience|PC1}, {@spell clairvoyance|PC1}, {@spell dream message|PC1}, and {@spell illusory disguise|PC1}. The eligible spells granted by the most prominent types of hag are: {@b Cuckoo Hag} {@spell nightmare|PC1}, {@spell spellwrack|PC1}; {@b Iron Hag} {@spell earthbind|PC1}, {@spell spellwrack|PC1}; {@b Sea Hag} {@spell humanoid form|PC1}, {@spell mariner's curse|PC1}, {@spell water walk|PC1}; {@b Sweet Hag} {@spell charm|PC1}, {@spell honeyed words|PC1}, {@spell outcast's curse|PC1}

feat.name: Angelkin
entries: You descend from an angel, a winged messenger from Nirvana or one of the other celestial realms. You gain the trained proficiency rank in {@skill Society|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in {@skill Society|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You know the {@language Empyrean|PC1} language, and you gain the {@feat Multilingual|PC1} skill feat.

feat.name: Grimspawn
entries: Your lineage traces back to a daemon, one of the manifestations of horrific forms of death that devour souls within their foul home of Abaddon. As a result, you cling tenaciously to the last shreds of your own life force. You gain the {@feat Diehard|PC1} general feat.

feat.name: Hellspawn
entries: Your lineage descends from devils, conniving schemers of Hell. You're as skilled at noticing lies and twisted wordings as you are at constructing them. You are trained in {@skill Deception|PC1} and {@skill Lore|PC1|Legal Lore}. If you were already trained in {@skill Deception|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice. You also gain the {@feat Lie to Me|PC1} skill feat.

feat.name: Lawbringer
entries: You trace your lineage to archons, guardians of the seventiered mountain of Heaven and nurturers of law and virtue within mortals. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saves against {@trait emotion} effects, and if you roll a success on a save against an {@trait emotion} effect, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Musetouched
entries: Your blood sings with the liberating power of the azatas, living embodiments of freedom from the wild realm of Elysium. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@action Escape|PC1}. When you roll a critical failure on a check to {@action Escape|PC1}, you get a failure instead, and when you roll a success, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Pitborn
entries: Your blood bears the mark of a demon, a living embodiment of sin from the fetid depths of the Outer Rifts. Demonic power pulses through your veins and manifests in a different way for each pitborn, whether you have webbed fingers and thrive in the water, large hands capable of wrestling larger foes, or some other manifestation. You are trained in {@skill Athletics|PC1}. If you were already trained in {@skill Athletics|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.

You also gain any one {@filter common 1st-level skill feat|feats||type=skill|Level=[1]|skill=athletics|rarity=common} with a prerequisite of trained in {@skill Athletics|PC1}, as reflects the manifestation of your fiendish blood.

feat.name: Bestial Manifestation
entries: Part of your body has an animalistic influence from a planar creature. Your hands end in claws, you have hooves instead of feet, sharp teeth fill your mouth, or a tail extends from your spine. You gain your choice of one of the following unarmed attacks. The attack is in the brawling group and has the listed damage die and traits.

{@b Claw} {@damage 1d4} slashing (agile, finesse, unarmed, versatile piercing) {@b Hoof} {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning (finesse, unarmed) {@b Jaws} {@damage 1d6} piercing (finesse, unarmed) {@b Tail} {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning (agile, finesse, unarmed)
special: You can select this feat only at 1st level, and you can't retrain into or out of this feat, nor can you change the type of attack you gained.

feat.name: Halo
entries: You have a halo of light and goodness that sheds light with the effects of a {@trait divine} {@spell light|PC1} cantrip. A cantrip is heightened to a spell rank equal to half your level rounded up. You can {@action Sustain|PC1} to suppress or reestablish the halo.

feat.name: Nephilim Eyes
entries: Your eyes can see through darkness with visual acuity akin to that possessed by most extraplanar beings. You gain darkvision.

feat.name: Nephilim Lore
entries: You know the secrets of the Multiverse. You gain the trained proficiency rank in either {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} or {@skill Intimidation|PC1}, and {@skill Religion|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.
You also gain the {@feat Additional Lore|PC1} general feat for a {@skill Lore|PC1} subcategory of a plane to which you trace your lineage.

feat.name: Nimble Hooves
entries: You possess hooves, ankle wings, or some other feature that hastens your movement. Your Speed increases by 5 feet.
special: The Speed increase from this feat isn't cumulative with any Speed increase from other ancestry feats.

feat.name: Blessed Blood
entries: Your spilled blood is sanctified, with effects similar to those of {@item holy water|GMC}. Whenever a fiend, undead, or creature with a weakness to holy drinks your blood or deals piercing or slashing damage to you with jaws, fangs, or a similar attack, that creature takes {@damage 1d6} spirit damage with the {@trait holy|PC1} trait. You gain a +4 circumstance bonus to {@skill Crafting|PC1} checks to {@action Craft|PC1} holy water using your blood as one of the ingredients.

feat.name: Extraplanar Supplication
entries: You call upon divine power to place a benediction upon your allies or a malediction upon your foes. Choose either {@spell bless|PC1} or {@spell bane|PC1}. You can cast the chosen spell once per day as a 1st-rank divine innate spell.

feat.name: Nephilim Resistance
entries: You resist energy like your extraplanar predecessors. Choose one of the following energy damage types: acid, cold, electricity, fire, or sonic. You gain resistance 5 to that damage type.

The damage type typically matches an extraplanar entity associated with your bloodline. For instance, an {@feat angelkin|PC1} might choose resistance to cold, while a {@feat hellspawn|PC1} might choose resistance to fire.

feat.name: Scion of Many Planes
entries: The long and complicated history of your bloodline manifests in your ability to draw power from more planar sources than most other nephilim. Choose one nephilim lineage feat that you do not already possess; you gain that feat and all of its benefits, even if you already took a lineage feat at 1st level.

feat.name: Skillful Tail
entries: You've always had a tail, but with practice, you've learned to use it for more than signaling your mood. You can perform simple {@action Interact|PC1} actions with your tail, such as opening an unlocked door. Your tail can't perform actions that require fingers or significant manual dexterity, including any action that would require a check to accomplish, and you can't use it to hold items.

feat.name: Celestial Magic
feat.prerequisites: {@feat Angelkin|PC1}, {@feat Lawbringer|PC1}, {@feat Musetouched|PC1}, or another lineage feat associated with celestials
entries: You possess celestial magic. Choose two of the following spells: {@spell clear mind|PC1}, {@spell everlight|PC1}, {@spell humanoid form|PC1}, {@spell revealing light|PC1}, {@spell share life|PC1}, or {@spell sure footing|PC1}. You can use each of the chosen spells once per day as 2nd-rank divine innate spells.

Angelkin typically take {@spell clear mind|PC1} and {@spell humanoid form|PC1}, lawbringers typically have {@spell everlight|PC1} and {@spell share life|PC1}, and musetouched typically have {@spell revealing light|PC1} and {@spell sure footing|PC1}.

feat.name: Divine Countermeasures
entries: You've studied your extraplanar heritage with the intent of better defending yourself, whether against creatures aligned with or opposed to your extraplanar lineage, and you've found that your techniques are equally powerful against celestials, fiends, and other divine entities. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to all saving throws against {@trait divine} effects.

feat.name: Divine Wings
entries: With effort, you can call forth magical wings from your back, similar in appearance to those of your extraplanar forebear, whether they be elegantly feathered wings or ominous bat wings. These wings remain for 10 minutes. You gain a fly Speed equal to your Speed while you've manifested your wings.

feat.name: Fiendish Magic
entries: You possess fiendish magic. Choose two of the following spells: {@spell disguise magic|PC1}, {@spell false vitality|PC1}, {@spell invisibility|PC1}, {@spell see the unseen|PC1}, {@spell shatter|PC1}, or {@spell paranoia|PC1}. You can use each of the chosen spells once per day as 2nd-rank divine innate spells.

{@featGrimspawn|PC1} typically take {@spell false vitality|PC1} and {@spell see the unseen|PC1}, {@featpitborn|PC1} typically take {@spell paranoia|PC1} and {@spell shatter|PC1}, and {@feathellspawn|PC1} typically take {@spell invisibility|PC1} and {@spell disguise magic|PC1}.

feat.name: Celestial Mercy
feat.prerequisites: {@feat Angelkin|PC1}, {@feat Lawbringer|PC1}, {@feat Musetouched|PC1}, or another lineage feat associated with celestials
entries: Your celestial powers allow you to remove lesser afflictions with ease. You can cast {@spell cleanse affliction|PC1} twice per day as a 4th-rank divine innate spell.

feat.name: Slip Sideways
feat.prerequisites: {@feat Grimspawn|PC1}, {@feat Pitborn|PC1}, or {@feat Hellspawn|PC1}, or another lineage feat associated with fiends or the Maelstrom
entries: Like many fiends, you have the supernatural ability to teleport yourself to safety. Once per day, you can cast {@spell translocate|PC1} as a 5th-rank divine innate spell.

feat.name: Summon Nephilim Kin
entries: You have a connection to the Outer Planes, allowing you to summon a divine ally. Choose either {@spell summon celestial|PC1}, {@spell summon fiend|PC1}, or another 5th-rank spell capable of summoning an extraplanar creature appropriate to your lineage. Once per day, you can cast the chosen spell as a 5th-rank divine innate spell, but the creature summoned must be from the same category as your own lineage, such as a creature with the {@trait angel} trait if you are an {@feat angelkin|PC1}.

feat.name: Divine Declaration
entries: You can call forth a holy or unholy word from the realms beyond to punish your foes. Once per day, you can cast {@spell divine decree|PC1} as a 7th-rank divine innate spell.

feat.name: Eternal Wings
entries: Your wings are now a permanent part of your body. You gain the effects of Divine Wings at all times, rather than just once per day for 10 minutes.

feat.name: Earned Glory
entries: Elves often struggle with underestimating aiuvarins, and you are experienced at telling stories of your accomplishments to gain their respect. You are trained in {@skill Performance|PC1}. If you would automatically become trained in {@skill Performance|PC1} (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.

You gain the {@feat Impressive Performance|PC1} feat. When you attempt a {@skill Performance|PC1} check to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} on an elf, if you roll a critical failure, you get a failure instead.

feat.name: Elf Atavism
entries: Your elven blood runs particularly strong, granting you features far more elven than those of a typical aiuvarin. You may also have been raised among elves, steeped in your elven ancestors' heritage. You gain the benefits of the elf heritage of your elven parent or ancestors. You typically can't select a heritage that depends on or improves an elven feature you don't have. For example, you couldn't take the {@ancestry elf|PC1|Ancient Elf|ancient|PC1} heritage unless your non-elf ancestry also has a lifespan measured in multiple centuries. In these cases, at the GM's discretion, you might gain a different benefit.
special: You can take this feat only at 1st level, and you can't retrain out of this feat or into this feat.

feat.name: Inspire Imitation
entries: Your actions inspire your allies to great achievements. Whenever you critically succeed at a skill check, you automatically qualify to use the {@action Aid|PC1} reaction when attempting to help an ally using the same skill, even without spending an action to prepare to do so.

feat.name: Supernatural Charm
entries: The elven magic in your blood manifests as a force you can use to become more appealing or alluring. You can cast 1st-rank {@spell charm|PC1} as an arcane innate spell once per day.

feat.name: Monstrous Peacemaker
entries: Your dual human and orc nature has given you a unique perspective, allowing you to bridge the gap between humans and the many {@trait intelligent} creatures in the world that humans consider monsters. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} checks against non-humanoid {@trait intelligent} creatures and against humanoids that are marginalized in human society (at the GM's discretion, but typically at least including giants, goblins, kobolds, and orcs). You also gain this bonus on {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to Sense the Motives of such creatures.

feat.name: Orc Sight
entries: Your orc blood grants you the keen vision of your forebears. You gain darkvision, allowing you to see in darkness and dim light just as well as you can in bright light. However, in darkness, you see in black and white only.
special: You can take this feat only at 1st level, and you can't retrain out of this feat or into this feat.

feat.name: Bardic Lore
entries: Your studies make you informed on every subject. You are trained in {@skill Lore|PC1|Bardic Lore}, a special {@skill Lore|PC1} skill that can be used only to {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1}, but on any topic. If you have legendary proficiency in {@skill Occultism|PC1}, you gain expert proficiency in {@skill Lore|PC1|Bardic Lore}, but you can't increase your proficiency rank in {@skill Lore|PC1|Bardic Lore} by any other means.

feat.name: Hymn of Healing
entries: You learn the {@spell hymn of healing|PC1} composition spell, which imbues your music with rich melodies that help your allies recover from harm.

feat.name: Lingering Composition
entries: By adding a flourish, you make your compositions last longer. You learn the {@spell lingering composition|PC1} focus spell.

feat.name: Martial Performance
entries: Your muse has taught you how to handle a wider variety of weapons than most bards, empowering you to effortlessly blend your performance into combat tools. When you have a {@spell courageous anthem|PC1} composition cantrip active, and you damage an enemy with a {@action Strike|PC1}, the spell's duration is extended by 1 round. You can extend an individual casting only once in this way.
If you gain the {@spell rallying anthem|PC1} or {@spell song of strength|PC1} composition cantrips, you can apply this benefit to those cantrips as well.

feat.name: Reach Spell
entries: You can extend your spells' range. If the next action you use is to {@action Cast a Spell|PC1} that has a range, increase that spell's range by 30 feet. As is standard for increasing spell ranges, if the spell normally has a range of touch, you extend its range to 30 feet.

feat.name: Versatile Performance
entries: You can rely on the grandeur of your performances rather than ordinary social skills. You can use {@skill Performance|PC1} instead of {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} and instead of {@skill Intimidation|PC1} to {@action Demoralize|PC1}. You can also use an acting {@skill Performance|PC1} instead of {@skill Deception|PC1} to {@action Impersonate|PC1}.

In addition, you can use your proficiency rank in {@skill Performance|PC1} to meet the prerequisites of skill feats that require a particular proficiency rank in {@skill Deception|PC1}, {@skill Diplomacy|PC1}, or {@skill Intimidation|PC1}.

feat.name: Well-Versed
entries: You're resilient to performative influences that aren't your own. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against effects with the auditory, illusion, linguistic, {@trait sonic}, or {@trait visual} traits.

feat.name: Cantrip Expansion
entries: Study broadens your range of simple spells. Add two additional cantrips from your spell list to your repertoire.

feat.name: Directed Audience
entries: You can shape the area of your composition spells.

Whenever you cast a composition spell whose area is an emanation, you can change the spell's area to a cone 10 feet larger, to a maximum of twice the original area. For example, you could modify a composition spell that affects a 30-foot emanation to affect a 40-foot cone, but a 5-foot emanation could only become a 10-foot cone.

feat.name: Emotional Push
feat.trigger: An enemy you're aware of fails its save against an emotion spell.
entries: You prepare to take advantage of your enemy's sudden change in emotions. The target is {@condition off-guard|PC1} against your next attack before the end of your next turn.

feat.name: Esoteric Polymath
entries: You keep a book of occult spells, similar to a wizard's spellbook, and can use its spells to supplement your spell repertoire. Add all the spells in your repertoire to this book for free. You can use the {@skill Occultism|PC1} skill to {@action Learn Spells|Learn a Spell} and add them to your spellbook by paying the appropriate cost.

During your daily preparations, choose any one spell from your book of occult spells. If that spell is already in your spell repertoire, you can treat it as an additional signature spell that day. If it isn't in your repertoire, treat it as though it were until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Loremaster's Etude
entries: You magically unlock memories, making them easier to recall. You learn the {@spell loremaster's etude|PC1} composition spell.

feat.name: Multifarious Muse
entries: Your muse doesn't fall into a single label. Choose a type of muse other than that of your own. You gain a 1st-level feat that requires that muse, and your muse is now also a muse of that type, allowing you to take feats with the other muse as a prerequisite. You don't gain any of the other effects of the muse you chose.
special: You can take this feat multiple times. Each time you do, you must choose a different type of muse other than that of your own.

feat.name: Song of Strength
entries: Your performances inspire strength in your allies to aid them at physical tasks. You learn the {@spell song of strength|PC1} composition cantrip.

feat.name: Uplifting Overture
entries: You learn the {@spell uplifting overture|PC1} composition cantrip, which aids your allies' skills with the inspiring nature of your performance.

feat.name: Combat Reading
