entries: Even in the worst circumstances, you can perform basic tasks. Choose a skill you're trained in. You can forgo rolling a skill check for that skill to instead receive a result of 10 + your proficiency bonus (do not apply any other bonuses, penalties, or modifiers).
special: You can select this feat multiple times. Each time, choose a different skill and gain the benefits for that skill.

feat.name: Automatic Knowledge
feat.prerequisites: expert in a skill with the {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} action, {@feat Assurance|PC1} in that skill
entries: You know basic facts off the top of your head. Choose a skill you're an expert in that has the {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} action and for which you have the {@feat Assurance|PC1} feat. You can use the {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} action with that skill as a free action once per round. If you do, you must use {@feat Assurance|PC1} on the skill check.
special: You can select this feat multiple times, choosing a different skill each time. You can use Automatic Knowledge with any skills you have chosen, but you can still use Automatic Knowledge only once per round.

feat.name: Bargain Hunter
entries: You can {@action Earn Income|PC1} using {@skill Diplomacy|PC1}, spending your days hunting for bargains and reselling at a profit. You can also spend time specifically sniffing out a great bargain on an item; this works as if you were using {@action Earn Income|PC1} with {@skill Diplomacy|PC1}, except instead of gaining money, you purchase the item at a discount equal to the money you would have gained, gaining the item for free if your earned income equals or exceeds its cost. Finally, if you select Bargain Hunter during character creation at 1st level, you start play with an additional 2 gp.

feat.name: Battle Cry
entries: When you roll initiative, you can yell a mighty battle cry and {@action Demoralize|PC1} an {@condition observed|PC1} foe as a free action. If you're legendary in {@skill Intimidation|PC1}, you can use a reaction to {@action Demoralize|PC1} your foe when you critically succeed at an attack roll.

feat.name: Battle Medicine
feat.requirements: You're holding or wearing a healer's toolkit.
entries: You can patch up wounds, even in combat. Attempt a {@skill Medicine|PC1} check with the same DC as for {@action Treat Wounds|PC1} and restore the corresponding amount of HP; this doesn't remove the {@condition wounded|PC1} condition. As with {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}, you can attempt checks against higher DCs if you have the minimum proficiency rank. The target is then immune to your Battle {@skill Medicine|PC1} for 1 day. This does not make them immune to, or otherwise count as, {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}

feat.name: Bizarre Magic
entries: You can draw upon strange variations in your spellcasting, whether or not you can cast occult spells. The DCs to Recognize Spells you cast and {@action Identify Magic|PC1} you use increase by 5.

feat.name: Bonded Animal
entries: You forge strong connections with animals. You can spend 7 days of downtime regularly interacting with a normal animal (not a companion or other special animal) that is {@condition friendly|PC1} or {@condition helpful|PC1} to you. After this duration, attempt a {@skill Nature|PC1} check against the animal's Will DC. If successful, you bond with the animal. The animal is permanently bonded to you until you form a bond with a different animal or do something egregious to break your bond.

A {@condition helpful|PC1} animal is easier to direct. If your bonded animal is level –1, it gains the {@trait minion} trait, allowing you to command it more efficiently. The maximum level of creature that can be your minion increases to 3 if you're a master in {@skill Nature|PC1} and to 11 if you're legendary.
special: You can't have both a bonded animal and an animal companion (though you can have both a bonded animal and a pet or familiar).

feat.name: Break Curse
entries: You spend 8 hours praying or performing occult rites over the target, weakening a curse's power over them. Attempt to counteract the curse, using {@skill Occultism|PC1} or {@skill Religion|PC1} for your counteract check and half your level rounded up for the counteract rank. Break Curse only takes 10 minutes of prayer and rites if you are legendary in {@skill Occultism|PC1} or {@skill Religion|PC1}.

feat.name: Breath Control
entries: You can breathe even in hazardous or sparse air. You can hold your breath for 25 times as long as usual before suffocating. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to saving throws against inhaled threats, such as inhaled poisons, and if you roll a success on such a saving throw, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Canny Acumen
entries: Your avoidance or observation is beyond the ken of most in your profession. Choose Fortitude saves, Reflex saves, Will saves, or {@skill Perception|PC1}. You become an expert in your choice. At 17th level, you become a master in your choice.

feat.name: Cat Fall
entries: Your catlike aerial acrobatics allow you to cushion your falls. Treat falls as 10 feet shorter. If you're an expert in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, treat falls as 25 feet shorter and 50 feet if you're a master. If you're legendary in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, you always land on your feet and don't take damage, regardless of the distance of the fall.

feat.name: Charming Liar
entries: Your charm allows you to win over those you lie to. When you get a critical success using the {@action Lie|PC1} action, the target's attitude toward you improves by one step, as though you'd succeeded at using {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} to {@action Make an Impression|PC1}. This works only once per conversation, and if you critically succeed against multiple targets using the same result, you choose one creature's attitude to improve. You must be lying to impart seemingly important information, inflate your status, or ingratiate yourself, which trivial or irrelevant lies can't achieve.

feat.name: Cloud Jump
entries: You unparalleled athletic skill allows you to jump impossible distances. Triple the distance you {@action Long Jump|PC1} (so you could jump 60 feet on a successful DC 20 check). When you {@action High Jump|PC1}, use the calculation for a {@action Long Jump|PC1} but don't triple the distance.

You can jump a distance greater than your Speed by spending additional actions when you {@action Long Jump|PC1} or {@action High Jump|PC1}. For each additional action spent, add your Speed to the limit on how far you can {@action Leap|PC1}.

feat.name: Combat Climber
entries: |Your techniques allow you to fight as you climb. You're not {@condition off-guard|PC1} while Climbing and can Climb with a hand occupied. You must still use another hand and both legs to Climb.

feat.name: Communal Crafting
entries: You can have other PCs help you {@action Craft|PC1} an item, under your direction. A helper PC rolls a check with a skill in which they're trained. The skill must be {@skill Crafting|PC1} or another skill relevant to the item, as determined by the GM. For example, a PC might use {@skill Religion|PC1} to help you {@action Craft|PC1} an item with the {@trait divine} trait or {@skill Lore|PC1|Warfare Lore} to help you {@action Craft|PC1} a weapon. Your roll still determines whether you successfully create the item. Any helper's roll contributes toward reducing the cost of raw materials using the numbers from the {@action Earn Income|PC1} table; this uses the ally PC's proficiency rank in the skill and their level – 1 for their level.

Helping PCs must accompany you throughout the {@action Craft|PC1} activity (preventing them from pursuing other downtime activities) or the benefit is lost. The GM might determine that only a certain number of PCs can help depending on the circumstances.
Communal {@skill Crafting|PC1} also allows you to take the role of a helper when someone else is crafting, provided they accept your help

feat.name: Confabulator
entries: Even when caught in falsehoods, you pile lie upon lie. Reduce the circumstance bonus a target gains for your previous attempts to {@action Create a Diversion|PC1} or {@action Lie|PC1} to it from +4 to +2. If you're a master in {@skill Deception|PC1}, reduce the bonus to +1, and if you're legendary, your targets don't get these bonuses at all.

feat.name: Continual Recovery
entries: You zealously monitor a patient's progress to administer treatment faster. When you {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}, your patient becomes immune for only 10 minutes instead of 1 hour. This applies only to your {@action Treat Wounds|PC1} activities, not any other the patient receives.

feat.name: Courtly Graces
entries: You were raised among the nobility or have learned proper etiquette and bearing, allowing you to present yourself as a noble and play games of influence and politics. Unless you are intentionally presenting yourself differently, anyone who speaks with you will assume you are a noble or closely associated with the nobility (such as a prominent servant). You can use {@skill Society|PC1} to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} on a noble, as well as with {@action Impersonate|PC1} to pretend to be a type of noble or a specific individual noble. If you use the normal skills in those situations, you receive a +1 circumstance bonus to the check instead.

feat.name: Craft Anything
entries: You can find ways to craft just about anything, despite restrictions. As long as you have the appropriate {@skill Crafting|PC1} skill feat (such as {@feat Magical Crafting|PC1} for magic items) and meet the item's level and proficiency requirements, you ignore just about any other requirement, such as being of a specific ancestry or providing spells. If a requirement adds to the item's cost, you must still pay it (including castings of spells that themselves have a cost). You can't ignore requirements of special items that have exclusive means of access and {@skill Crafting|PC1}, such as artifacts. The GM decides whether you can ignore a requirement.

feat.name: Diehard
entries: It takes more to kill you than most. You die from the {@condition dying|PC1} condition at {@condition dying||dying 5}, rather than {@condition dying||dying 4}.

feat.name: Divine Guidance
entries: You're so immersed in divine scripture that you find meaning and guidance for any situation in your texts. Spend 10 minutes {@action Decipher Writing||Deciphering Writing} on religious scriptures of your deity or philosophy while thinking about a particular problem or conundrum you face, and then attempt a {@skill Religion|PC1} check (DC determined by the GM). If you succeed, you unearth a relevant passage, parable, or aphorism that can help you move forward or change your thinking to help solve your conundrum.

feat.name: Dubious Knowledge
feat.prerequisites: trained in a skill with the {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} action
entries: You're a treasure trove of information, but not all of it comes from reputable sources. When you fail (but don't critically fail) a {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} check using any skill, you learn the correct answer and an erroneous answer, but you don't have any way to differentiate which is which. This can occur as not knowing something is significant, but not whether it's good or bad.

feat.name: Expeditious Search
entries: You have a system that lets you search at great speed, finding details and secrets twice as quickly as others can. When Searching, you take half as long as usual to {@action Search|PC1} a given area. This means that while exploring, you double the Speed you can move while ensuring you've Searched an area before walking into it (up to half your Speed). If you're legendary in {@skill Perception|PC1}, you instead {@action Search|PC1} areas four times as quickly.

feat.name: Experienced Professional
entries: You carefully safeguard your professional endeavors to prevent disaster. When you use {@skill Lore|PC1} to {@action Earn Income|PC1}, if you roll a critical failure, you instead get a failure. If you're an expert in {@skill Lore|PC1}, you gain twice as much income from a failed check to {@action Earn Income|PC1}, unless it was originally a critical failure.

feat.name: Experienced Smuggler
entries: You often smuggle things past the authorities. When the GM rolls your {@skill Stealth|PC1} check to see if a passive observer notices a small item you've {@condition concealed|PC1}, the GM uses the number rolled or 10—whichever is higher—as the result of your die roll, adding it to your {@skill Stealth|PC1} modifier to determine your {@skill Stealth|PC1} check result. If you're a master in {@skill Stealth|PC1}, the GM uses the number rolled or 15, and if you're legendary in {@skill Stealth|PC1}, you automatically succeed at hiding a small {@condition concealed|PC1} item from passive observers. This provides no benefits when a creature attempts a {@skill Perception|PC1} check while actively searching you for {@condition hidden|PC1} items.

feat.name: Experienced Tracker
entries: Tracking is second nature to you, and when necessary you can follow a trail without pause. You can {@action Track|PC1} while moving at full Speed by taking a –5 penalty to your {@skill Survival|PC1} check. If you're a master in {@skill Survival|PC1}, you don't take the –5 penalty. If you're legendary in {@skill Survival|PC1}, you no longer need to roll a new {@skill Survival|PC1} check every hour when tracking, though you still need to roll whenever there are significant changes in the trail.

feat.name: Fascinating Performance
entries: When you {@action Perform|PC1}, compare your result to the Will DC of one observer. If you succeed, the target is {@condition fascinated|PC1} by you for 1 round. If the observer is in a situation that demands immediate attention, such as combat, you must critically succeed to fascinate it and the {@action Perform|PC1} action gains the {@trait incapacitation} trait. You must choose which creature you're trying to fascinate before you roll your check, and the target is then temporarily immune for 1 hour.

If you're an expert in {@skill Performance|PC1}, you can fascinate up to four observers; if you're a master, you can fascinate up to 10 observers; and if you're legendary, you can fascinate any number of observers at the same time.

feat.name: Fast Recovery
entries: Your body quickly bounces back from afflictions. You regain twice as many Hit Points from resting. Each time you succeed at a Fortitude save against an ongoing disease or poison, you reduce its stage by 2, or by 1 against a virulent disease or poison.

Each critical success you achieve against an ongoing disease or poison reduces its stage by 3, or by 2 against a virulent disease or poison. In addition, you reduce the severity of your {@condition drained|PC1} condition by 2 when you rest for a night instead of by 1.

feat.name: Feather Step
entries: You step carefully and quickly. You can {@action Step|PC1} into difficult terrain.

feat.name: Fleet
entries: You move more quickly on foot. Your Speed increases by 5 feet.

feat.name: Foil Senses
entries: You are adept at foiling creatures' special senses and cautious enough to safeguard against them at all times. Whenever you use the {@action Avoid Notice|PC1}, {@action Hide|PC1}, or {@action Sneak|PC1} actions, you are always considered to be taking precautions against special senses (see the Detecting with Other Senses sidebar).

feat.name: Forager
entries: While using {@skill Survival|PC1} to {@action Subsist|PC1}, if you roll any result worse than a success, you get a success. On a success, you can provide subsistence living for yourself and four additional creatures, and on a critical success, you can take care of twice as many additional creatures. You can choose to support half the number of creatures with a comfortable living.
Increase the number of additional creatures you feed on a success to eight if you're an expert in {@skill Survival|PC1}, 16 if you're a master, and 32 if you're legendary.

feat.name: Glad-Hand
entries: First impressions are your strong suit. When you meet someone in a casual or social situation, you can immediately attempt a {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} check to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} on that creature rather than needing to converse for 1 minute. If you fail, you can engage in 1 minute of conversation and attempt a new check at the end of that time rather than accepting the failure or critical failure result.

feat.name: Group Coercion
entries: You can strong-arm people effectively, even when you don't have them isolated. When you {@action Coerce|PC1}, you can compare your {@skill Intimidation|PC1} check result to the Will DCs of up to five targets instead of one.

It's possible to get a different degree of success for each target. The number of targets you can {@action Coerce|PC1} in a single action increases to 10 if you're an expert, 25 if you're a master, and 50 if you're legendary.

feat.name: Group Impression
entries: When you {@action Make an Impression|PC1}, you can compare your {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} check result to the Will DCs of up to 10 targets you conversed with, with no penalty. The number of targets increases to 20 if you're an expert, 50 if you're a master, and 100 if you're legendary.

feat.name: Hefty Hauler
entries: You can carry more than your frame implies. Increase your maximum and {@condition encumbered|PC1} Bulk limits by 2.

feat.name: Hobnobber
entries: You are skilled at learning information through conversation. The {@action Gather Information|PC1} exploration activity takes you half as long as normal (typically reducing the time to 1 hour). If you're a master in {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} and roll a critical failure to {@action Gather Information|PC1}, you get a failure instead. There is still no guarantee that a rumor you learn with {@action Gather Information|PC1} is accurate.

feat.name: Impeccable Crafting
entries: You craft flawless creations with great efficiency. Whenever you roll a success at a {@skill Crafting|PC1} check to make an item of the type you chose with {@feat Specialty Crafting|PC1}, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Impressive Performance
entries: Your performances inspire admiration and win you fans. You can {@action Make an Impression|PC1} using {@skill Performance|PC1} instead of {@skill Diplomacy|PC1}. If you spend at least 10 minutes performing in front of an audience, you can {@action Make an Impression|PC1} targeting up to 10 members of the audience who were there for the whole performance, without taking the normal penalty. The number of targets increases to 20 for a 1-hour performance and 50 for a 2-hour performance.

feat.name: Incredible Initiative
entries: You react more quickly than others can. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative rolls.

feat.name: Incredible Investiture
entries: You have an incredible ability to invest more magic items. Increase your limit on invested items from 10 to 12.

feat.name: Intimidating Glare
entries: You can {@action Demoralize|PC1} with a mere glare. When you do, {@action Demoralize|PC1} loses the {@trait auditory} trait and gains the {@trait visual} trait, and you don't take a penalty if the creature doesn't understand your language.

feat.name: Intimidating Prowess
entries: In situations where you can physically menace the target when you {@action Coerce|PC1} or {@action Demoralize|PC1}, you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your {@skill Intimidation|PC1} check and you ignore the penalty for not sharing a language. If your Strength modifier is +5 or higher and you are a master in {@skill Intimidation|PC1}, this bonus increases to +2.

feat.name: Inventor
entries: You are a genius at {@skill Crafting|PC1}, easily able to determine how things are made and create new inventions. You can spend downtime to invent a common formula that you don't know. This works just like the {@action Craft|PC1} activity: you spend half the Price of the formula up front, attempt a {@skill Crafting|PC1} check, and on a success either finish the formula by paying the difference or work for longer to decrease the Price. The difference is that you spend the additional time in research, design, and development, rather than in creating an item. Once it's complete, you add the new formula you invented to your formula book.

The GM might allow you to invent uncommon or rare formulas, typically with an increased DC. You need the {@feat Alchemical Crafting|PC1} feat to invent alchemical formulas and the {@feat Magical Crafting|PC1} feat to invent magical formulas.

feat.name: Kip Up
entries: You stand up. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.

feat.name: Lasting Coercion
entries: When you successfully {@action Coerce|PC1} someone, the maximum time they comply increases to a week, still determined by the GM. If you're legendary, the maximum increases to a month.

feat.name: Legendary Codebreaker
entries: Your skill with languages and codes is so great that you can decipher information with little more than a quick read through a text. You can {@action Decipher Writing|PC1} using {@skill Society|PC1} while reading at normal speed. If you slow down and spend the full amount of time that's ordinarily required and roll a success, you get a critical success; if you critically succeed while spending the normal amount of time, you gain a nearly word-for-word understanding of the document.

feat.name: Legendary Linguist
entries: You're so skilled with languages you can create a pidgin instantly. You can always talk to any creature that has a language—even a language you don't know—by creating a new pidgin language that uses simplified terms and conveys basic concepts. To do so, you must first understand at least what medium of communication the creature uses (speech, sign language, and so on).

feat.name: Legendary Medic
entries: You've discovered medical breakthroughs or techniques that achieve miraculous results. Once per day for each target, you can spend 1 hour treating that target and attempt a {@skill Medicine|PC1} check to remove a disease or the {@condition blinded|PC1}, {@condition deafened|PC1}, {@condition doomed|PC1}, or {@condition drained|PC1} condition. Use the DC of the disease or of the spell or effect that created the condition. If the effect's source is an artifact, above 20th level, or similarly powerful, increase the DC by 10.

feat.name: Legendary Negotiation
entries: You can negotiate incredibly quickly in adverse situations. You attempt to {@action Make an Impression|PC1} and then {@action Request|PC1} your opponent cease their current activity and engage in negotiations. You take a –5 penalty to your {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} check. Generally, the DC of this check is the creature's Will DC, although your GM may modify it based on the situation. Some creatures may be unable to stop regardless of their personal desires, and even those who agree to parley might ultimately find your arguments lacking and return to violence.

feat.name: Legendary Performer
entries: Your fame has spread throughout the lands. Creatures who have any listed skill in {@skill Society|PC1} have heard of you and usually have an attitude toward you one step better than normal, depending on your reputation and the creature's disposition. For instance, if you're well-known for cruel and demanding behavior, creatures might be intimidated by you, rather than be {@condition friendly|PC1} toward you. When you {@action Earn Income|PC1} with {@skill Performance|PC1}, you attract higher-level audiences than your location would allow, as audiences flock to see you. For instance, rulers and angels might travel to your small tower in the woods to hear you perform. Typically, this increases the audiences available to your level or by two levels, whichever is higher.

feat.name: Legendary Professional
entries: Your fame has spread throughout the lands (for instance, if you have {@skill Lore|PC1|Warfare Lore}, you might be a legendary general or tactician). This works as {@feat Legendary Performer|PC1} above, except you gain higher-level jobs when you {@action Earn Income|PC1} with {@skill Lore|PC1}.

feat.name: Legendary Sneak
entries: You're always sneaking unless you choose to be seen, even when there's nowhere to hide. You can {@action Hide|PC1} and {@action Sneak|PC1} even without cover or being {@condition concealed|PC1}. When you employ an exploration tactic other than {@action Avoid Notice||Avoiding Notice}, you also gain the benefits of {@action Avoid Notice||Avoiding Notice} unless you choose not to.

feat.name: Legendary Survivalist
entries: You can survive indefinitely without food or water and can endure severe, extreme, and incredible cold and heat without taking damage from doing so.

feat.name: Legendary Thief
entries: Your ability to {@action Steal|PC1} defies belief. You can attempt to {@action Steal|PC1} something that is actively wielded or that would be extremely noticeable or time consuming to remove (like worn shoes or armor). You must do so slowly and carefully, spending at least 1 minute (and significantly longer for items that are normally time consuming to remove, like armor). Throughout this duration you must have some means of staying {@condition hidden|PC1}, such as the cover of darkness or a bustling crowd. Even if you succeed, if the item is extremely prominent—like a suit of full plate armor—onlookers will quickly notice it's gone after you steal it.

feat.name: Lengthy Diversion
entries: When you critically succeed to {@action Create a Diversion|PC1}, you continue to remain {@condition hidden|PC1} after the end of your turn. This effect lasts for an amount of time that depends on the diversion and situation, as determined by the GM (minimum 1 additional round).

feat.name: Lie to Me
entries: You can use {@skill Deception|PC1} to weave traps to trip up anyone trying to deceive you. If you can engage in conversation with someone trying to {@action Lie|PC1} to you, use your {@skill Deception|PC1} DC if it is higher than your {@skill Perception|PC1} DC to determine whether they succeed. This doesn't apply if you don't have a back-and-forth dialogue, such as when someone attempts to {@action Lie|PC1} during a long speech.

feat.name: Magical Crafting
entries: You can {@action Craft|PC1} magic items, though some have other requirements, as listed in GM Core. When you select this feat, you gain formulas for four common magic items of 2nd level or lower.

feat.name: Magical Shorthand
feat.prerequisites: expert in {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1}
entries: Learning spells comes easily to you. When you succeed at {@action Learn a Spell||Learning a Spell}, it takes 10 minutes regardless of the spell's rank. If you would succeed on the check, you critically succeed instead. If you fail, you can try again after a week or after you gain a level, whichever is first.

You can use downtime to learn and inscribe new spells. This works as if you were using {@action Earn Income|PC1} with the tradition's associated skill, but instead of gaining money, you choose a spell available to you to learn and gain a discount on learning it, learning it for free if your earned income equals or exceeds its cost.

feat.name: Monster Crafting
entries: You can use the parts of monsters to aid in crafting. You can use the body of a monster to help {@action Craft|PC1} items, using {@skill Survival|PC1} instead of {@skill Crafting|PC1} for the {@action Craft|PC1} activity when you do so. If parts of the monster's body are valuable, you can expend them toward the item's raw material cost as well. (The GM makes the determination if the monster's entry doesn't list any valuable materials from its body.)

If you spend additional days working on the item, reduce the Price using the monster's level instead of your own. Certain items may require specific creatures in their {@action Craft|PC1} requirement.

feat.name: Multilingual
entries: You easily pick up new languages. You learn two new languages, chosen from common languages, uncommon languages, and any others you have access to. You learn an additional language if you are or become a master in {@skill Society|PC1} and again if you are or become legendary.
special: You can select this feat multiple times. Each time, you learn additional languages.

feat.name: Natural Medicine
entries: You can apply natural cures to heal your allies. You can use {@skill Nature|PC1} instead of {@skill Medicine|PC1} to {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}, including higher {@skill Nature|PC1} proficiency letting you attempt more difficult checks. It doesn't replace {@skill Medicine|PC1} for uses of the skill other than {@action Treat Wounds|PC1} or for feat prerequisites.

If you're in the wilderness, you might have easier access to fresh ingredients, allowing you to gain a +2 circumstance bonus to your check to {@action Treat Wounds|PC1} using {@skill Nature|PC1}, subject to the GM's determination.

feat.name: Nimble Crawl
entries: You can {@action Crawl|PC1} incredibly swiftly—up to half your Speed, rather than 5 feet. If you're a master in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, you can {@action Crawl|PC1} at full Speed, and if you're legendary, you aren't {@condition off-guard|PC1} while prone.

feat.name: No Cause for Alarm
entries: You attempt to reduce panic. Attempt a {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} check, comparing it to the Will DC of creatures in a 10-foot emanation around you who are {@condition frightened|PC1}. Each of them is temporarily immune for 1 hour.

Critical Success: Reduce the creature's {@condition frightened|PC1} value by 2.
Success: Reduce the creature's {@condition frightened|PC1} value by 1.

feat.name: Oddity Identification
entries: When you become aware of a {@trait magical} effect or see a spell being cast, you can immediately determine if it twists minds (with the {@trait mental} trait), fights against fortune (with the {@trait fortune} or {@trait misfortune} trait), or reveals secrets (with the detection, prediction, {@trait revelation}, or {@trait scrying} traits). At the GM's discretion, similar effects can also fall into these categories. When you {@action Identify Magic|PC1} or {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} to learn more about these effects, you can always use {@skill Occultism|PC1} without penalty and gain a +2 circumstance bonus.

feat.name: Pet
entries: You have a pet—a Tiny animal of a type you choose, such as a cat, bird, or rodent. It has the {@trait minion} trait, meaning it gains 2 actions during your turn if you use the {@action Command an Animal|PC1} action to command it; this replaces the usual effects of {@action Command an Animal|PC1}, and you don't need to attempt a {@skill Nature|PC1} check. A pet can't make Strikes.
{@b Level} Your pet's level is equal to yours.

{@b Modifiers and AC} Your pet's save modifiers and AC are equal to yours before applying circumstance or status bonuses or penalties. It uses 3 + your level as its modifier for {@skill Perception|PC1}, {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, and {@skill Stealth|PC1}, and just your level as its modifier for other skill checks. It doesn't have or use its own attribute modifiers and can never benefit from item bonuses.
{@b Hit Points} Your pet has 5 Hit Points per level.
{@b Senses} Your pet has low-light vision and can gain additional senses from pet abilities.

{@b Speed} Your pet has a Speed of 25 feet. You can choose to instead have an aquatic pet, which breathes in water instead of air and has the {@trait aquatic} trait, no land Speed, and a swim Speed of 25 feet.

{@b Pet Abilities} When you gain your pet, choose two of the following abilities. If your pet is an animal that naturally has one of these abilities (for instance, an owl has a fly Speed), you must select that ability. Your pet can't be an animal that naturally has more pet abilities than the maximum. In some cases, the GM might add some familiar abilities to the pet abilities you can choose.

items: {@b Amphibious} It gains the {@trait amphibious} trait, allowing it to breathe in both air and water, and has both a land Speed and a swim Speed, each equal to its highest land Speed or swim Speed.
{@b Burrower} It gains a burrow Speed of 5 feet, allowing it to dig Tiny holes.
{@b Climber} It gains a climb Speed of 25 feet.
{@b Darkvision} It gains darkvision.
{@b Echolocation} Your pet can use hearing as a precise sense within 20 feet.
{@b Fast Movement} Increase one of the pet's Speeds from 25 feet to 40 feet.
{@b Flier} It gains a fly Speed of 25 feet.
{@b Manual Dexterity} It can use up to two of its limbs as if they were hands to perform manipulate actions.
{@b Scent} Your pet can use scent as an imprecise sense within 30 feet
{@b Tough} Your pet's max HP increase by 2 per level.

special: You can gain a new pet by retraining this feat, releasing any previous pet you have. If you later gain a familiar or other companion that uses the Pet feat, you can immediately retrain this feat.

feat.name: Pickpocket
entries: You can {@action Steal|PC1} or {@action Palm an Object|PC1} that's closely guarded, such as in a pocket, without taking the –5 penalty. You can't steal objects that would be extremely noticeable or time consuming to remove (like worn shoes or armor or actively wielded objects). If you're a master in {@skill Thievery|PC1}, you can attempt to {@action Steal|PC1} from a creature in combat or otherwise on guard. When doing so, Stealing requires 2 actions instead of 1, and you take a –5 penalty.

feat.name: Planar Survival
entries: You can {@action Subsist|PC1} using {@skill Survival|PC1} on different planes, even those without resources or natural phenomena you normally need. For instance, you can forage for food without penalty even if the plane lacks food that could normally sustain you. A success on your check to {@action Subsist|PC1} also prevents damage done by the plane to you and anyone else you support with {@action Subsist|PC1}. This applies only to damage dealt by the general conditions of the plane, not smaller hazards.

feat.name: Powerful Leap
entries: You can jump 5 feet up with a vertical {@action Leap|PC1} without making a {@action High Jump|PC1}. You also increase the horizontal distance when you {@action Leap|PC1}, including as part of a {@action High Jump|PC1} or {@action Long Jump|PC1}, by 5 feet.

feat.name: Prescient Consumable
entries: You can predict which consumables you might need in advance. When using Prescient Planner, you can procure a consumable item from your backpack, instead of a piece of adventuring gear. The consumable item must still be common with a level no higher than half your level, and its Bulk must be low enough that carrying it wouldn't have made you {@condition encumbered|PC1}.

feat.name: Prescient Planner
feat.cost: the Price of the chosen item
feat.requirements: You haven't used this ability since the last time you were able to purchase goods.
entries: You regularly create convoluted plans and contingencies, using your resources to enact them. You take 1 minute to remove your backpack, then carefully remove an item you hadn't previously declared that you purchased—you intuited that you would come to need the item and purchased it at the latest opportunity. The item must be a piece of adventuring gear (from the table on page 291 or other sources of adventuring gear), and can't be a weapon, armor, alchemical item, magic item, or other treasure. It must be common with a level no higher than half your level, and its Bulk must be low enough that carrying it wouldn't have made you {@condition encumbered|PC1}.

feat.name: Quick Climb
entries: When Climbing, you move 5 more feet on a success and 10 more feet on a critical success, up to your Speed. If you're legendary in {@skill Athletics|PC1}, you gain a climb Speed equal to your Speed.

feat.name: Quick Coercion
entries: You can bully others with just a few choice implications. You can {@action Coerce|PC1} a creature after 1 round of conversation instead of 1 minute. You still can't {@action Coerce|PC1} a creature in the midst of combat, or without engaging in a conversation.

feat.name: Quick Disguise
entries: You can set up a disguise in one-tenth the usual time (generally 1 minute). If you're a master in {@skill Deception|PC1}, you can create a full disguise and {@action Impersonate|PC1} as a 3-action activity. If you're legendary, it takes a single action.

feat.name: Quick Identification
feat.prerequisites: trained in {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1} or {@skill Religion|PC1}
entries: You can {@action Identify Magic|PC1} swiftly. You take only 1 minute when using {@action Identify Magic|PC1} to determine the properties of an item, ongoing effect, or location, rather than 10 minutes. If you're a master, it takes a 3-action activity, and if you're legendary, it takes 1 action.

feat.name: Quick Jump
entries: You can use {@action High Jump|PC1} and {@action Long Jump|PC1} as a single action instead of 2 actions. If you do, you don't perform the initial {@action Stride|PC1} (nor do you fail if you don't {@action Stride|PC1} 10 feet).

feat.name: Quick Recognition
feat.prerequisites: master in {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1}
entries: Recognize Spell You Recognize Spells swiftly. Once per round, you can Recognize a Spell using a skill in which you're a master as a free action.

feat.name: Quick Repair
entries: For you, the {@action Repair|PC1} activity loses the {@trait exploration} trait and takes 1 minute instead of 10 minutes. If you're a master in {@skill Crafting|PC1}, it takes 3 actions. If you're legendary, it takes 1 action.

feat.name: Quick Squeeze
entries: You {@action Squeeze|PC1} 5 feet per round (10 feet on a critical success). If you're legendary in {@skill Acrobatics|PC1}, you {@action Squeeze|PC1} at full Speed.

feat.name: Quick Swim
entries: You {@action Swim|PC1} 5 feet farther on a success and 10 feet farther on a critical success, to a maximum of your Speed. If you're legendary in {@skill Athletics|PC1}, you gain a swim Speed equal to your Speed.

feat.name: Quick Unlock
entries: You can {@action Pick a Lock|PC1} using 1 action instead of 2.

feat.name: Quiet Allies
entries: You're skilled at moving with a group. When you are {@action Avoid Notice||Avoiding Notice} and your allies {@action Follow the Expert|PC1}, you and those allies can roll a single {@skill Stealth|PC1} check, using the lowest modifier, instead of rolling separately. This doesn't apply for initiative rolls.

feat.name: Rapid Mantel
entries: You easily pull yourself onto ledges. When you {@action Grab an Edge|PC1}, you can pull yourself onto that surface and stand. You can use {@skill Athletics|PC1} instead of a Reflex save to {@action Grab an Edge|PC1}. If you {@action Climb|PC1} or {@action Leap|PC1} to within 5 feet beneath the top of an edge, you can pull yourself onto the surface and stand as part of that action.

feat.name: Read Lips
entries: You can read lips of others nearby who you can clearly see. The language read must be one that you know. When you're at your leisure, you can do this automatically. In encounter mode or when attempting a more difficult feat of lipreading, you're {@condition fascinated|PC1} and {@condition off-guard|PC1} during each round in which you focus on lip movements, and you must succeed at a {@skill Society|PC1} check (DC determined by the GM) to successfully read someone's lips.

feat.name: Recognize Spell
feat.prerequisites: trained in {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1}
feat.trigger: A creature within line of sight casts a spell that you don't have prepared or in your spell repertoire, or a trap or similar object casts such a spell. You must be aware of the casting.
entries: If you are trained in the appropriate skill for the spell's tradition and it's a common spell of 2nd rank or lower, you automatically identify it (you still roll to attempt to get a critical success, but can't get a worse result than success). The highest rank of spell you automatically identify increases to 4 if you're an expert, 6 if you're a master, and 10 if you're legendary. The GM rolls a secret {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1} check, whichever corresponds to the tradition of the spell being cast. If you're not trained in the skill, you can't get a result better than failure.

Critical Success: You correctly recognize the spell and gain a +1 circumstance bonus to your saving throw or your AC against it.
Failure: You fail to recognize the spell.
Critical Failure: You misidentify the spell as another spell entirely, of the GM's choice.

feat.name: Robust Recovery
entries: You learned folk medicine to help recover from diseases and poison, and using it diligently has made you especially resilient.

When you Treat a Disease or a Poison, or someone else uses one of these actions on you, increase the circumstance bonus granted on a success to +4, and if the result of the patient's saving throw is a success, the patient gets a critical success.

feat.name: Scare to Death
entries: You can frighten foes so much, they might die. Attempt an {@skill Intimidation|PC1} check against the Will DC of a living creature within 30 feet of you that you sense or observe and who can sense or observe you. If the target can't hear you or doesn't understand the language you are speaking, you take a –4 circumstance penalty. The creature is temporarily immune for 1 minute.

Critical Success: The target must attempt a Fortitude save against your {@skill Intimidation|PC1} DC. On a critical failure, it dies. On any other result, it becomes {@condition frightened||frightened 2} and is {@condition fleeing|PC1} for 1 round. The critical failure effect has the {@trait death} trait.

feat.name: Schooled in Secrets
entries: You notice the signs and symbols that members of mystery cults and other secret societies use to declare their affiliation to fellow members. You can use {@skill Occultism|PC1} in place of {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} to {@action Gather Information|PC1} about such groups and in place of {@skill Deception|PC1} to {@action Impersonate|PC1} a member of these groups. If you belong to a secret cult, lodge, sect, or similar organization, you automatically recognize members of your group unless they are specifically attempting to conceal their presence from you. They also recognize your standing unless you are specifically concealing it.

feat.name: Seasoned
feat.prerequisites: trained in {@skill Lore|PC1|Alcohol Lore}, {@skill Lore|PC1|Cooking Lore}, or {@skill Crafting|PC1}
entries: You've mastered the preparation of many types of food and drink. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to checks to {@action Craft|PC1} food and drink, including elixirs if you have {@feat Alchemical Crafting|PC1} and potions if you have {@feat Magical Crafting|PC1}. If you are a master in one of the prerequisite skills, this bonus increases to +2.

feat.name: Shameless Request
feat.requirements: master in {@skill Diplomacy|PC1}
entries: You can downplay the consequences or outrageousness of your requests using sheer brazenness and charm. When you {@action Request|PC1} something, you reduce any DC increases for making an outrageous request by 2, and if you roll a critical failure for your {@action Request|PC1}, you get a failure instead. While this means you can never cause your target to reduce their attitude toward you by making a {@action Request|PC1}, they eventually tire of requests, even though they still have a positive attitude toward you.

feat.name: Shield Block
feat.trigger: While you have your shield raised, you would take physical damage (bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing) from an attack.
entries: You snap your shield in place to ward off a blow. Your shield prevents you from taking an amount of damage up to the shield's Hardness. You and the shield each take any remaining damage, possibly breaking or destroying the shield.

feat.name: Sign Language
entries: You learn the sign languages associated with the languages you know, allowing you to sign and understand signs. Sign languages typically require both hands to convey more complex concepts, and they are visual rather than auditory.

Sign language is difficult to understand during combat due to the level of attention needed, unlike basic gestures like pointing at a foe to suggest a target. Sign language is hard to use in areas of low visibility, just like speech is difficult in a noisy environment.

feat.name: Skill Training
entries: You become trained in the skill of your choice.
special: You can select this feat multiple times, choosing a new skill to become trained in each time.

feat.name: Slippery Secrets
entries: You elude and evade attempts to uncover your true nature or intentions. When a spell or {@trait magical} effect tries to read your mind, detect whether you are lying, or reveal your identity, you can attempt a {@skill Deception|PC1} check against the spell or effect's DC. If you succeed, the effect reveals nothing.

feat.name: Specialty Crafting
entries: Your training focused on {@skill Crafting|PC1} one particular kind of item. Select one of the specialties listed below; you gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Crafting|PC1} checks to {@action Craft|PC1} items of that type. If you are a master in {@skill Crafting|PC1}, this bonus increases to +2.

If it's unclear whether the specialty applies, the GM decides. Some specialties might apply only partially. For example, if you were making a morningstar and had specialty in woodworking, the GM might give you half your bonus because the item requires both blacksmithing and woodworking.

rows: Durable metal goods, including {@filter metal armor|items||group=plate;chain;composite}

feat.name: Steady Balance
entries: You can keep your balance easily, even in adverse conditions. Whenever you roll a success using the {@action Balance|PC1} action, you get a critical success instead. You're not {@condition off-guard|PC1} while attempting to {@action Balance|PC1} on narrow surfaces and uneven ground. Thanks to your incredible balance, you can attempt an {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} check instead of a Reflex save to {@action Grab an Edge|PC1}.

feat.name: Streetwise
entries: You know about life on the streets and feel the pulse of your local settlement. You can use your {@skill Society|PC1} modifier instead of your {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} modifier to {@action Gather Information|PC1}. In any settlement you frequent regularly, you can use the {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} action with {@skill Society|PC1} to know the same sorts of information that you could discover with {@skill Diplomacy|PC1} to {@action Gather Information|PC1}. The DC is usually significantly higher, but you know the information without spending time gathering it. If you fail to recall the information, you can still subsequently attempt to {@action Gather Information|PC1} normally.

feat.name: Student of the Canon
entries: You've researched many faiths enough to recognize notions about them that are unlikely to be true. If you roll a critical failure at a {@skill Religion|PC1} check to {@action Decipher Writing|PC1} of a religious nature or to {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} about the tenets of faiths, you get a failure instead. When attempting to {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} about the tenets of your own faith, if you roll a failure, you get a success instead, and if you roll a success, you get a critical success instead.

feat.name: Subtle Theft
entries: When you successfully {@action Steal|PC1} something, observers (creatures other than the creature you stole from) take a –2 circumstance penalty to their {@skill Perception|PC1} DCs to detect your theft. Additionally, if you first {@action Create a Diversion|PC1} using {@skill Deception|PC1}, taking a single {@action Palm an Object|PC1} or {@action Steal|PC1} action doesn't end your {@condition undetected|PC1} condition.

feat.name: Survey Wildlife
entries: You can study details in the wilderness to determine the presence of nearby creatures. You can spend 10 minutes assessing the area around you to find out what creatures are nearby, based on nests, scat, and marks on vegetation. Attempt a {@skill Survival|PC1} check against a DC determined by the GM based on how obvious the signs are. On a success, you can attempt a {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} check with a –2 penalty to learn more about the creatures just from these signs. If you're a master in {@skill Survival|PC1}, you don't take the penalty.

feat.name: Swift Sneak
entries: You can move your full Speed when you {@action Sneak|PC1}. You can use Swift {@action Sneak|PC1} while Burrowing, Climbing, Flying, or Swimming instead of Striding if you have the corresponding movement type.

feat.name: Terrain Expertise
entries: Your experience in navigating a certain type of terrain makes you supremely confident while doing so. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to {@skill Survival|PC1} checks in one of the following types of terrain, chosen when you select this feat: aquatic, arctic, desert, forest, mountain, plains, sky, swamp, or underground.
special: You can select this feat more than once, choosing a different type of terrain each time.

feat.name: Terrain Stalker
entries: Select one type of difficult terrain from the following list: rubble, snow, or underbrush. While {@condition undetected|PC1} by all non-allies in that type of terrain, you can {@action Sneak|PC1} without attempting a {@skill Stealth|PC1} check as long as you move no more than 5 feet and do not pass within 10 feet of an enemy during your movement.
During exploration, this also allows you to automatically approach within 15 feet of other creatures while Avoiding their Notice, as long as they aren't actively Searching or on guard.
special: You can select this feat multiple times. Each time, choose a different type of terrain.

feat.name: Terrified Retreat
entries: When you critically succeed at the {@action Demoralize|PC1} action, if the target's level is lower than yours, the target is {@condition fleeing|PC1} for 1 round.

feat.name: Titan Wrestler
entries: You can attempt to {@action Disarm|PC1}, {@action Grapple|PC1}, {@action Reposition|PC1}, {@action Shove|PC1}, or {@action Trip|PC1} creatures up to two sizes larger than you, or up to three sizes larger than you if you're legendary in {@skill Athletics|PC1}.

feat.name: Toughness
entries: Your body can withstand more punishment than most before succumbing. Increase your maximum Hit Points by your level. You reduce the DC of recovery checks by 1.

feat.name: Train Animal
entries: You spend time teaching an animal to do a certain action. You can either select a basic action the animal already knows how to do (typically those listed in the {@action Command an Animal|PC1} action) or attempt to teach the animal a new basic action. The GM determines the DC of any check required and the amount of time the training takes (usually at least a week). It's usually impossible to teach an animal a trick that uses critical thinking. If you're expert, master, or legendary in {@skill Nature|PC1}, you might be able to train more unusual creatures, at the GM's discretion.

Success: The animal learns the action. If it was an action the animal already knew, you can Command the Animal to take that action without attempting a {@skill Nature|PC1} check. If it was a new basic action, add that action to the actions the animal can take when Commanded, but you must still roll.
Failure: The animal doesn't learn the trick.

feat.name: Trick Magic Item
feat.prerequisites: trained in {@skill Arcana|PC1}, {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1}
entries: You examine a magic item you normally couldn't use in an effort to fool it and activate it temporarily. For example, this might allow a fighter to cast a spell from a wand or allow a wizard to cast a spell that's not on the arcane list using a scroll. You must know what activating the item does, or you can't attempt to trick it.

Attempt a check using the skill matching the item's magic tradition, or matching a tradition that has the spell on its list, if you're trying to cast a spell from the item. The relevant skills are {@skill Arcana|PC1} for arcane, {@skill Nature|PC1} for primal, {@skill Occultism|PC1} for occult, {@skill Religion|PC1} for divine, or any of the four for an item that has the {@trait magical} trait and not a tradition trait. The GM determines the DC based on the item's level (possibly adjusted depending on the item or situation).

If you activate a magic item that requires a spell attack modifier or spell DC and you don't have the ability to cast spells of the relevant tradition, use your level as your proficiency bonus and the highest of your Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma modifiers. If you're a master in the appropriate skill for the item's tradition, you instead use the trained proficiency bonus; if you're legendary, you instead use the expert proficiency bonus.

Success: For the rest of the current turn, you can spend actions to activate the item as if you could normally use it.
Failure: You can't use the item or try to trick it again this turn, but you can try again on subsequent turns.
Critical Failure: You can't use the item, and you can't try to trick it again until your next daily preparations.

feat.name: Underwater Marauder
entries: You've learned to fight underwater. You are not {@condition off-guard|PC1} while in water, and you don't take the usual penalties for using a bludgeoning or slashing melee weapon in water.

feat.name: Unified Theory
entries: You understand the common underpinnings of the four traditions of magic and magical essences, allowing you to understand them all through an arcane lens. Whenever you use a skill action or a skill feat that requires a {@skill Nature|PC1}, {@skill Occultism|PC1}, or {@skill Religion|PC1} check, depending on the magic tradition, you can use {@skill Arcana|PC1} instead. If you would normally take a penalty or have a higher DC for using {@skill Arcana|PC1} on other magic (such as when using {@action Identify Magic|PC1}), you no longer do so.

feat.name: Unmistakable Lore
entries: You never get information about your areas of expertise wrong. When you {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} using any {@skill Lore|PC1} subcategory in which you're trained, if you roll a critical failure, you get a failure instead. If you're a master in a {@skill Lore|PC1} subcategory, on a critical success, you gain even more information or context than usual.

feat.name: Untrained Improvisation
entries: You've learned how to handle situations when you're out of your depth. Your proficiency bonus to untrained skill checks is equal to your level –2. This improves to your level –1 at 5th level and your full level at 7th level. This doesn't allow you to use the skill's trained actions.

feat.name: Unusual Treatment
entries: Your medical training extends to less obvious conditions. When you succeed against a DC 20 check to {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}, you can also reduce the value of one {@condition clumsy|PC1}, {@condition enfeebled|PC1}, or {@condition stupefied|PC1} condition on the patient by 1. If you're able to treat more than one creature at once, choose only one to gain this benefit. A creature can benefit from Unusual Treatment only once per day.
If the condition results from an affliction, the affliction isn't cured, though the condition is reduced as long as the affliction remains at that stage.

If you are a master in {@skill Medicine|PC1}, add the {@condition drained|PC1} condition to the list of conditions you can remove if you succeed at a DC 30 check. If you are legendary in {@skill Medicine|PC1}, you reduce the chosen condition by 2 instead of by 1.

feat.name: Virtuosic Performer
entries: You have exceptional talent with one type of performance. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus when making a certain type of performance. If you are a master in {@skill Performance|PC1}, this bonus increases to +2. Select one of the following specialties and apply the bonus when attempting {@skill Performance|PC1} checks of that type. If it's unclear whether the specialty applies, the GM decides.

feat.name: Wall Jump
entries: You can use your momentum from a jump to propel yourself off a wall. If you're adjacent to a wall at the end of a jump (whether performing a {@action High Jump|PC1}, {@action Long Jump|PC1}, or {@action Leap|PC1}), you don't fall as long as your next action is another jump. Your previous jump gives you momentum, letting you use {@action High Jump|PC1} or {@action Long Jump|PC1} as a single action, but you don't get to {@action Stride|PC1} as part of the activity.
You can use Wall Jump only once in a turn, unless you're legendary in {@skill Athletics|PC1}, in which case you can use it as many times as you can use consecutive jump actions in that turn.

feat.name: Ward Medic
entries: You've studied in large medical wards, treating several patients at once and tending to all their needs. When you use {@action Treat Disease|PC1} or {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}, you can treat up to two targets. If you're a master in {@skill Medicine|PC1}, you can treat up to four targets, and if you're legendary, you can treat up to eight targets.

feat.name: Wary Disarmament
entries: If you trigger a device or set off a trap while disarming it, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to your AC or saving throw against the device or trap. This applies only to attacks or effects triggered by your failed attempt, not to any later ones, such as additional attacks from a complex trap.

feat.name: Weapon Proficiency
entries: You become trained in all martial weapons. If you were already trained in all martial weapons, you become trained in one advanced weapon of your choice. If you are at least 11th level, you also become an expert in these weapons.
special: You can select this feat more than once. Each time you do, you become trained in an advanced weapon.
